{{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Crisscross heart | image = | caption = | | pronounce = | field = | synonyms = | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }} '''Crisscross heart''' is a type of [[Congenital heart defect|congenital]] heart defect where the [[right atrium]] is closely associated with the [[left ventricle]] in space, and the [[left atrium]] is closely associated with the [[right ventricle]].<ref name="pmid2312210">{{cite journal | vauthors = Fontes VF, de Souza JA, Pontes Jùnior SC | title = Criss-cross heart with intact ventricular septum | journal = International Journal of Cardiology | volume = 26 | issue = 3 | pages = 382–5 | date = March 1990 | pmid = 2312210 | doi = 10.1016/0167-5273(90)90102-B }}</ref>
Although it is classified as a defect, the criss-cross is more of a spatial anomaly than a functional one, and it is possible for the heart to have relatively normal functioning. The ventricles are rotated either clockwise or counterclockwise resulting in the twisting of their connection<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Angelini P | title = Left ventricle on top versus right ventricle on top in superoinferior ventricles: what are we talking about? | journal = Texas Heart Institute Journal | volume = 37 | issue = 4 | pages = 442–4 | date = 2010 | pmid = 20844618 | pmc = 2929877 }}</ref>. The actual blood flow stream through the ventricles is not interrupted.
== Properties of an anatomically correct heart == In an anatomically correct heart the [[Atrium (heart)|right atrium]] and [[Ventricle (heart)|right ventricle]] are working together to supply blood to the [[Artery|pulmonary artery]], similarly to how the left atrium and the left ventricle work simultaneously to supply blood to the [[aorta]]. During the process of the heart contracting and releasing the right atrium and left atrium contract at the same time, while the left ventricle and right ventricle relax. In opposition, when the left atrium and right atrium are relaxed the left ventricle and right ventricle contract pushing blood to either the aorta or pulmonary artery. In an anatomically correct heart the atria are smaller than the ventricles. The ventricles include more muscle in order to push high quantities of blood throughout the body. Normal blood flow throughout the heart begins at the [[superior vena cava]] coming from the upper half of the body and the [[inferior vena cava]] coming from the lower half of the body. Next blood will be in the right atrium and will flow uninterrupted through the [[tricuspid valve]] through to the right ventricle. The blood from the right ventricle should go to the pulmonary artery via the pulmonary valve.The blood from the pulmonary vein enters the left atrium, then flows through the mitral valve to the left ventricle. After the left ventricle is filled with blood the aortic valve opens allowing blood to go through, which the blood then enters the aorta and goes to the rest of the body<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.chop.edu/pages/how-normal-heart-works|title=How the Normal Heart Works|last=Philadelphia|first=The Children's Hospital of|date=2014-08-10|website=www.chop.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-25}}</ref>.
== Symptoms == Crisscross heart is a very rare congenital heart defect, and results in many different symptoms, even though the heart still has the ability to perform its major function of pumping blood throughout the body. Individuals who have this disease will experience [[cyanosis]] which is a blue tint to the skin because of inadequate blood flow to the body, this symptom will be seen especially around the mouth. Other symptoms include [[pallor]], extreme [[Shortness of breath|dyspnea]], [[pulmonary valve stenosis]], [[Heart murmur|cardiac murmurs]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://go.galegroup.com/ps/retrieve.do?tabID=T002&resultListType=RESULT_LIST&searchResultsType=SingleTab&searchType=AdvancedSearchForm&currentPosition=1&docId=GALE%7CA358238281&docType=Case+study&sort=Relevance&contentSegment=&prodId=AONE&contentSet=GALE%7CA358238281&searchId=R1&userGroupName=colu91149&inPS=true#|title=Gale - Product Login|website=go.galegroup.com|access-date=2018-10-25}}</ref> and a deviated ventricular septum<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.orpha.net/consor/cgi-bin/OC_Exp.php?Lng=GB&Expert=1461|title=Orphanet: Criss cross heart|last=RESERVED|first=INSERM US14 -- ALL RIGHTS|website=www.orpha.net|language=en|access-date=2018-10-25}}</ref>. Pallor can be described as a pale color of the skin, and dyspnea is difficulty breathing. Pulmonary valve stenosis is the narrowing of the pulmonary valve which leads to decreased blood flow to the pulmonary artery. Cardiac murmurs are sounds that can be heard when using a stethoscope that make a swooshing noise rather than a normal “lub-dup”. Lastly a deviated ventricular septum is when there is a hole between the ventricle walls resulting in blood between the ventricles flowing freely between each other<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Taksande AM | title = Echocardiographic recognition of a criss-cross heart with double outlet right ventricle | journal = Images in Paediatric Cardiology | volume = 15 | issue = 2 | pages = 3–7 | date = April 2013 | pmid = 23847656 | pmc = 3669543 }}</ref>.
== Diagnosis and Treatment == Crisscross heart can be diagnosed by an [[Echocardiography|echocardiogram]], [[Angiocardiography|angiocardiogram]], and a [[Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging|cardiac MRI]]. To diagnose crisscross heart during embryonic development a [[Medical ultrasound|sonogram]] will be used, and it is very important identify the disease prenatally so the child can be treated immediately for better cardiac function in adulthood<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Li S, Luo G, Norwitz ER, Wang C, Ouyang S, Yao Y, Wen H, Chen C, Fu Q, Xia X, Bi J, Zhu J | title = Prenatal diagnosis of criss-cross heart: sonographical and pathological features of five cases | language = En | journal = Journal of Perinatology | volume = 33 | issue = 2 | pages = 98–102 | date = February 2013 | pmid = 22555779 | doi = 10.1038/jp.2012.56 | url = http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/jp.2012.56 }}</ref>. Without treatment crisscross heart can be fatal. The treatment is aimed to fix a deviated septum and pulmonary valve stenosis rather than the rotated heart it self.

{{about|[[human]] tooth numbering|the general [[mammal]]ian dental formula|dentition|names of tooth surfaces|Glossary of dentistry}} Dental professionals, in writing or speech, use several different '''dental notation''' systems for associating information with a specific tooth. The three most common systems are the ISO System (ISO 3950, the [[FDI World Dental Federation notation]]), [[Universal Numbering System]], and [[Palmer Notation Method|Palmer notation method]]. The ISO system is used worldwide, and the Universal is used widely in the United States. The ISO System can be easily adapted to computerized charting.
Another system is used by [[paleoanthropologist]]s.
== History == A committee of the [[American Dental Association]] (ADA) recommended the use of the Palmer notation method in 1947. Since this method required the use of symbols, its use was difficult on keyboards. As a result, the association officially supported the Universal system in 1968. The [[World Health Organization]] and the [[Fédération Dentaire Internationale]] officially uses the two-digit numbering system of the FDI system. However, in 1996, the ADA adopted the ISO System as an alternative to the Universal System.
== ISO System by the World Health Organization == [[File:Teeth model front FDI Notation.jpg|thumb|FDI Notation, teeth's quadrants]]
The International Standards Organization Designation System (ISO System) by the World Health Organization notation system is widely used by dental professionals internationally to associate information with a specific tooth. Based on the Fédération Dentaire Internationale (FDI), it is also known as ISO 3950<ref>[http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_catalogue/catalogue_tc/catalogue_detail.htm?csnumber=41835 ISO 3950:2009 ''Dentistry — Designation system for teeth and areas of the oral cavity'']</ref> notation. Thus the ISO System uses a two-digit numbering system in which the first digit represents a tooth's quadrant and the second digit represents the number of the tooth from the midline of the face. For permanent teeth, the upper right teeth begin with the number, "1". The upper left teeth begin with the number, "2". The lower left teeth begin with the number, "3". The lower right teeth begin with the number, "4". For primary teeth, the sequence of numbers goes 5, 6, 7, and 8 for the teeth in the upper right, upper left, lower left, and lower right respectively. When speaking about a certain tooth such as the permanent maxillary central incisor, the notation is pronounced “one, one”. Beware of mixing up the teeth in written form such as 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18 between the Universal and ISO systems.
For example: retention of a primary molar tooth in the otherwise regular intact lower right jaw, position 5, would be noted as: 41, 42, 43, 44, 85, 46, 47, 48.<!-- Don't change "85" to "45"! -- it is a primary tooth. -->

== Palmer notation method ==
{{main article|Palmer Notation Method}}
The Palmer notation is a system used by dentists to associate information with a specific tooth. Although supposedly superseded by the [[FDI World Dental Federation notation]], it overwhelmingly continues to be the preferred method used by dental students and practitioners in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1111/j.1600-0579.1998.tb00034.x | vauthors = Blinkhorn A, Choi C, Paget H | title = An investigation into the use of the FDI tooth notation system by dental schools in the UK. | journal = Eur J Dent Educ | volume = 2 | issue = 1 | pages = 39–41 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9588962}}</ref> It was originally termed the "Zsigmondy system" after the Hungarian dentist [[Adolf Zsigmondy]] who developed the idea in 1861, using a ''Zsigmondy cross'' to record quadrants of tooth positions.<ref name="huszar">{{cite journal | author = Huszár G | title = [The role of the life and works of Adolf Zsigmondy and Ottó Zsigmondy in the history of dentistry][Article in Hungarian] | journal = Fogorv Sz | volume = 82 | issue = 12 | pages = 357–63 | year = 1989 | pmid = 2689240}}</ref><!-- NB not same as Richard Adolf Zsigmondy who won Nobel Prize for chemistry in 1925 --> Permanent teeth (adult) were numbered 1 to 8, and the child primary dentition (also called deciduous, milk or baby teeth) were depicted with a quadrant grid using Roman numerals I, II, III, IV, V to number the teeth from the midline distally. Palmer changed this to A, B, C, D, E.
The Palmer notation consists of a symbol (┘└ ┐┌) designating the quadrant of the tooth and a number indicating the position from the midline. Adult teeth are numbered 1 to 8, with primary teeth indicated by a letter A to E. Hence the left and right maxillary central incisor would have the same number, "1", but the right one would have the symbol, "┘", underneath it, while the left one would have, "└". {| class="nowrap" | Permanent Dentition upper right - 1x upper left - 2x {{color|blue|8 7 6 }}{{color|#dd00dd|5 4 }}{{color|#00dd00|3 }}{{color|#ffaa00|2 1 }}| {{color|#ffaa00|1 2 }}{{color|#00dd00|3 }}{{color|#dd00dd|4 5 }}{{color|blue|6 7 8 }} R --------------------------------------------------- L {{color|blue|8 7 6 }}{{color|#dd00dd|5 4 }}{{color|#00dd00|3 }}{{color|#ffaa00|2 1 }}| {{color|#ffaa00|1 2 }}{{color|#00dd00|3 }}{{color|#dd00dd|4 5 }}{{color|blue|6 7 8}} lower right - 4x lower left - 3x

== Universal numbering system == {{main article|Universal numbering system (dental)}}
Although it is termed "universal numbering system", it is most commonly used in the United States. It is also called the "American system".<ref>{{cite web|title=Histology: A Text and Atlas by Michael H. Ross • Wojciech Pawlina|url=https://www.inkling.com/read/histology-michael-ross-and-wojciech-pawlina-6th/chapter-16/folder-16-2}}</ref> The uppercase letters ''A'' through ''T'' are used for primary teeth and the numbers 1 - 32 are used for permanent teeth. The tooth designated "1" is the maxillary right third molar ("[[wisdom tooth]]") and the count continues along the upper teeth to the left side. Then the count begins at the mandibular left third molar, designated number 17, and continues along the bottom teeth to the right side. Each tooth has a unique '''number''' or '''letter''', allowing for easier use on keyboards.

==Notation used by paleoanthropologists== [[Paleoanthropologist]]s use a system suitable to other primates as well. The upper teeth are denoted I<sup>1</sup>, I<sup>2</sup>, C<sup>−</sup>, Pm<sup>3</sup>, Pm<sup>4</sup>, M<sup>1</sup>, M<sup>2</sup>, and M<sup>4</sup>. Left or right has to be specified. The lower teeth are I<sub>1</sub>, I<sub>2</sub>, C<sub>−</sub>, Pm<sub>3</sub>, Pm<sub>4</sub>, M<sub>1</sub>, M<sub>2</sub>, and M<sub>3</sub>. The reason the premolars are labeled 3 and 4 is that in earlier primates there were two other premolars between them and the canines.<ref>{{cite book|last1=[[Gentry Steele]] and [[Claud Bramblett]]|title=The Anatomy and Biology of the Human Skeleton|date=1988|isbn=9780890963265|pages=75, 82|url=https://books.google.fr/books?id=WedKmN3X86kC&pg=PA82&lpg=PA82&dq=pm3+premolar&source=bl&ots=aXxVtb_-mx&sig=_c8CAgorUdcS9AhaL1Xnu5JMHy0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj99eeV3MzUAhXlCMAKHe01DtwQ6AEIWTAL#v=onepage&q=pm3%20premolar&f=false}}</ref>
==Letters and numbers system== In this system, also known as ''alpha-numeric notation'', the four quadrants are designated as follows: * UR - upper right * UL - upper left * LR - lower right * LL - lower left
Within each quadrant, the teeth are numbered as in the Palmer notation: 1-8 for permanent and A-E for deciduous, both starting at the midline. For example, the permanent left maxillary first molar is designated '''UL6'''.
To prevent uncertainty or ambiguity, teeth may be indicated using more than one notation, particularly when referring for an extraction; this makes it less likely for the incorrect tooth to be needlessly extracted. For instance, a dentist may give an instruction to "extract the 24 (UL4) upper left first premolar tooth."

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2012}} {{EngvarB|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Devaka Fernando | image = DevakaFernando.jpg | image_size = | caption = | nationality = Sri Lankan | occupation = Physician | known_for = Professor of Medicine, University of Sri Jayawardanapura | title = Professor }}
'''Devaka Fernando''', [[Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery|MBBS]], [[Master of Science|MSc]], [[Doctor of Medicine|MD]], [[Fellow of the Royal College of Physicians|FRCP]], is a[[Sri Lankan people|Sri Lankan]] [[physician]] and academic. He was president of the [[Osteoporosis]] Society of Sri Lanka and a professor of medicine at the [[University of Sri Jayawardanapura]].
==Education== Fernando was educated at Dean Row School in [[Cheshire|Cheshire, UK]],<ref name=linkedin>{{cite web|url=http://uk.linkedin.com/pub/devaka-fernando/3/374/a62|title= Profile|publisher=www.linkedin.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-29}}</ref> [[Shore Country Day School]] in [[Beverly, Massachusetts]]<ref name=linkedin/> and [[S. Thomas' College, Mt Lavinia]], [[Sri Lanka]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.tyretracks.com/showthread.php?t=121|title= D.S.Jayasekera-Unassuming in disposition, he walked tall.Daily Mirror, 24 th August 2006|publisher=tyretracks.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.island.lk/index.php?page_cat=article-details&page=article-details&code_title=88905 | title=Sharm de Alwis Thomians honour Quentin Israel | work=The Island | date=26 September 2013 | accessdate=20 October 2013}}</ref> He received a [[Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery]] degree from the [[Faculty of Medicine, University of Colombo]]. Fernando received a [[Doctor of Medicine]] degree and membership of the Royal College of Physicians, trained in public health at the [[University of Manchester]] (Master of Science in Clinical Epidemiology) and trained as a specialist at the [[Manchester Royal Infirmary]].<ref name=linkedin/>
=={{anchor|Educational and professional activity}}Educational and professional activities== Fernando was a consultant physician in [[Diabetes mellitus|diabetes]] and the [[endocrinology]] department of the Sri Jayawardanapura General Hospital and a senior lecturer in the faculty of medicine at the University of Colombo.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://hettiarachchi.tripod.com/RAVI4.html|title = Prevention of non-communicable diseases - challenges in the next century Daily News, Saturday 28, February 1998 |publisher= hettiarachchi.tripod.com|accessdate=2011-09-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://dl.nsf.ac.lk/bitstream/1/10089/2/JCCP-32(1)-9.pdf|title = Prevention of non-communicable disease - challanges''[sic]'' in the next century Ravindra Fernando Journal of the Ceylon College of Physicians, 1999, 32, 9-18 |publisher= National Science Foundation|accessdate=2013-12-26}}</ref> He was a professor of medicine in the University of Sri Jayewardenepura faculty of health sciences,<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.dailynews.lk/2001/12/21/new20.html|title = Faculty of Graduate Studies third research sessions Daily News Friday, 21 December 2001|publisher= www.dailynews.lk|accessdate=2011-09-30}}</ref> coordinated the endocrinology training programme for the board of study in medicine at the [[University of Colombo]]'s [[Postgraduate Institute of Medicine]] from 1998 to 2004,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://endocrinesociety.wordpress.com/council/history/milestone/|title = Milestones in the history of the Endocrine Society of Sri Lanka |publisher= endocrinesociety.wordpress.com|accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref> managed the World Diabetes Foundation project in Sri Lanka,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sundaytimes.lk/060604/plus/Health.html|title = Diabetes is slowly but steadily rearing its head among the majority of Sri Lankans, and it’s time to take notice |publisher= sundaytimes.lk|accessdate=2011-11-15}}</ref> was editor and vice-president of the Diabetes Association of Sri Lanka and was the founding director of the Sri Lanka Twin Registry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sundaytimes.lk/981213/plus2.html|title = A National Twin Registry has been launched to facilitate research in this fascinating field The Sunday Times Sri Lanka 13th December 1998|publisher= sundaytimes.lk |accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.atypon-link.com/AAP/doi/pdf/10.1375/twin.5.5.424?cookieSet=1|title = Sri Lanka twin Registry|publisher= www.atypon-link.com |accessdate=2011-05-28|doi=10.1375/twin.5.5.424|volume=5|journal=Twin Research|pages=424–426}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://infolanka.com/org/twin-registry/Messages.htm|title = Message from Prof. Rohan Jayesekara, The Head of the Department of Anatomy and the Director of the Human Genetics Unit, Faculty of Medicine, University of Colombo , Sri Lanka|publisher= infolanka.com |accessdate=2012-12-20}}</ref> Fernando was a charter member of the board of study in medical administration at PGIM Colombo,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmasl.lk/news.php#df|title = A Seminar on Medical Management Professor Devaka Fernando MBBS MD FRCP FRCP (Edin) Msc, was the keynote speaker|publisher= www.cmasl.lk|accessdate=2012-01-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmasl.lk/photoGallery/index.php?sfpg=MjAxMSBDUEQxLyoqM2E4MjY1M2JkZjljNWRiZWE0MTRlNjI4YjE2Y2FiZDQ|title = A Seminar on Medical Management Professor Devaka Fernando |publisher= www.cmasl.lk|accessdate=2012-01-04}}</ref> was involved in the specialist training of doctors in Sri Lanka through the Royal College of Physicians<ref>{{cite web|url=http://old.rcplondon.ac.uk/pubs/clinicalmedicine/0502marapr/0502_marchapril_prof3.htm|title = International educational partnerships for doctors in training: a collaborative framework with the RCP|publisher= rcplondon.ac.uk |accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfh-tr.nhs.uk/content/showcontent.aspx?contentid=402|title = Partnership with colleagues in other countries |publisher= www.sfh-tr.nhs.uk|accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref> and was connected to efforts to prevent discrimination against diabetes patients.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.novoindia.com/prerana2/encount.htm|title = A Champion in the making: An Interview with Dayan Rathnajith|publisher= www.novoindia.com|accessdate=2012-11-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynews.lk/2001/11/16/fea06.html |title = Doctor and sportsman Edward Arambewela Ceylon daily News Friday 16th November 2001|publisher= www.dailynews.lk |accessdate=2012-11-30}}</ref> He had a health-policy advisory role on a World Bank project<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ihp.lk/research/project.html?project_id=NC-002|title = Rationalising NCD Care in the Maldives|publisher= www.ihp.lk |accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref> and engaging the media in diabetes care<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1002/pdi.1000|title = Engaging the media in diabetes prevention in Sri Lanka|publisher= | volume=23|journal=Practical Diabetes International|pages=335–337}}</ref> through the Diabetes Forum.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emdtr.org/projects/diabetesforum/diabetesforum.htm|title = A Diabetes Forum for the Sri Lankan health community |publisher= www.emdtr.org |accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref> Fernando was secretary in 1995 and 1997,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://issuu.com/slmanews/docs/slmanews_2012_09?mode=window&pageNumber=1|title =Dr Lucien Jayasuriya SLMA News September 2012 Volume 5 Issue 09 page 12|publisher= Slmanews |accessdate=2012-12-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://issuu.com/slmanews/docs/slmanews_2012_08|title=Dr S Ramachandran SLMA News August 2012 volume 5 Issue 08 page 16 |publisher=Slma.lk |date= |accessdate=2013-02-16}}</ref> treasurer in 1998 and vice-president in 2000 of the Sri Lanka Medical Association; secretary (1993–1996) and treasurer (1997–1998) of the Ceylon College of Physicians; founding president of the Osteoporosis Society of Sri Lanka (later named Osteoporosis Sri Lanka);<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iofbonehealth.org/about-iof/member-societies/society.html?societyID=181|title=Osteoporosis Sri Lanka Society News|publisher= www.iofbonehealth.org |date= |accessdate=2011-09-30}}</ref> from 2000 to 2004,<ref>{{cite web|url= http://sundaytimes.lk/000213/plus9.html|title = Osteoporosis society launched The Sunday Times 13th February 2000 |publisher= sundaytimes.lk|accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sundaytimes.lk/041017/plus/8.html|title=As a national survey on osteoporosis gets underway, Sunday Times |publisher= www.sundaytimes.lk |date=17 October 2004 |accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref> editor (1994–1995) and treasurer (1996–2000) of the Endocrine Society of Sri Lanka;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://endocrinesociety.wordpress.com/council/history/milestone/|title = Milestones in the history of the Endocrine Society of Sri Lanka |publisher= endocrinesociety.wordpress.com|accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref> part of a Sri Lanka task force for the eradication of rabies,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynews.lk/2002/04/26/fea06.html|title= Task Force to eradicate rabies |publisher=www.dailynews.lk |date= |accessdate=2012-11-30}}</ref> and charter committee members of the National Stroke Association of Sri Lanka<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archives.dailymirror.lk/2004/05/26/news/3.asp|title=Rienzie elected to head National Stroke Association|publisher=www.dailymirror.lk|date=|accessdate=2012-12-15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921055101/http://archives.dailymirror.lk/2004/05/26/news/3.asp|archivedate=21 September 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and the for the Brain Research and Neuroscience Centre's advisory panel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.btnrc.org/about-us/|title= Professor Devaka Fernando |publisher= www.btnrc.org |date=2012-10-01 |accessdate=2013-11-13}}</ref> While working in Sri Lanka, Fernando held clinical and research fellowships and senior research fellowships at the [[University of Manchester]], visiting professorships with the [[University of Newcastle Upon Tyne]] and the [[University of Sheffield]] and an honorary professorship at [[Sheffield Hallam University]];<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.shu.ac.uk/faculties/hwb/medical/staff-honorary.html |title = Sheffield Hallam University, Honorary Professors, Postgraduate Institute of Medical and Dental Education |publisher= shu.ac.uk|accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref> he later emigrated to the United Kingdom.
==Research==
===Publications=== {| class="wikitable" |+ Citation report |- | Total citations || 1157 |- | Citations without self-citations || 1128 |- | Citing articles{{clarify|date=March 2017}} || 1013 |- | Average citations per item || 12.31 |- | [[H-index]] || 17<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Devaka_Fernando/ |title =Devaka J S Fernando |publisher= www.researchgate.net|accessdate=2011-12-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pubfacts.com/author/Devaka+J+S+Fernando |title =Devaka Fernando |publisher= www.pubfacts.com|accessdate=2016-01-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://academic.research.microsoft.com/Author/49496977 |title =Devaka JS Fernando |publisher= academic.research.microsoft.com|accessdate=2015-05-28}}</ref> |}
===Grants=== Fernando has been an applicant or co-applicant in grants received from the [[Wellcome Trust]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/stellent/groups/corporatesite/@msh_publishing_group/documents/web_document/wtx053270.pdf|title = The Wellcome Trust Grants Awarded 2007/08|publisher= www.wellcome.ac.uk |accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref> and the World Diabetes Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worlddiabetesfoundation.org/composite-708.htm|title = Preventing Diabetes and NCDs|publisher= www.worlddiabetesfoundation.org |accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref>
==Professional affiliations and honors== He has received academic honors from: * The Ceylon College of Physicians ([[P. B. Fernando]] Gold Medal<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hellis.srilanka.healthrepository.org/handle/123456789/6136 |title=The Diabetic Foot |publisher= hellis.srilanka.healthrepository.org |date= |accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref> and [[Cyril Fernando]] Gold Medal)<ref>{{cite web|url= http://hellis.srilanka.healthrepository.org/handle/123456789/6214?mode=full&submit_simple=Show+full+item+record |title= The Clinical epidemiology of thyroid disease in Sri Lanka |publisher= hellis.srilanka.healthrepository.org|date= |accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref> * The Sri Lanka Medical Association (Sir [[Nicholas Attygalle]] Gold Medal)<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.slma.lk/sna.html|title =Sir Nicholas Attygalle Oration -List of Orators |publisher= slma.lk|date= |accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref> * The Kandy Society of Medicine ([[Seneka Bibile]] Gold Medal<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.island.lk/2006/02/13/news15.html |title =Lifestyle Diseases in Sri Lanka — a Medical Tsunami Kandy Society of Medicine annual sessions begin, The Island 13th February 2006 |publisher= island.lk|accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref> and the Kandy Society of Medicine Gold Medal for Oration)<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.theksm.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=55:31st-annual-academic-sessions&catid=35:upcoming-events-of-kandy-medical-society&Itemid=50|title =31st Annual Sessions|publisher=theksm.org|accessdate=2011-08-18}}</ref> * The College of General Practitioners of Sri Lanka (Gunasiri Memorial Oration Gold Medal and Cyril Vaz Memorial Gold Medal for Oration) * The Diabetes Association of Sri Lanka (Sir [[Frank Gunasekera]] Gold Medal for Oration) * The Andhra Pradesh Diabetes Federation (M. Viswanathan Gold Medal) With [[Victor Hettigoda]], Fernando received a presidential award for research.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundayleader.lk/2010/08/08/hettigoda-honoured/|title=Hettigoda honoured Sunday Leader|date=8 August 2010|publisher=the sunday leader.lk|accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref> He was made an honorary fellow of the College of General Practitioners of Sri Lanka and a fellow of the [[Royal College of Physicians]] in London and Edinburgh and the Ceylon College of Physicians.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sundaytimes.lk/981101/plus6.html|title=Ceylon College of Physicians Fellowships Sunday Times 1st November 1998|date=|publisher=www.sundaytimes.lk|accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref>
==Voluntary service== Fernando chaired the Endocrine and Metabolic Disease Trust, based in [[Dehiwala-Mount Lavinia]], [[Ratmalana]], from 1990 to 2004;<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.google.com/imgresimgurl=http://www.emdtr.org/projects/diabetesforum/Prog01_03_08_2007_files/director.jpg&imgrefurl=http://www.emdtr.org/projects/diabetesforum/Prog01_03_08_2007_files/Prog01_03_08_2007.htm&usg=__HeSE4Z2z61MO9DjQ7wQJPWl06KU=&h=176&w=130&sz=4&hl=en&start=10&zoom=0&um=1&itbs=1&tbnid=jsYIIMLTy1SOYM:&tbnh=100&tbnw=74&prev=/search%3Fq%3Ddevaka%2Bfernando%26um%3D1%26hl%3Den%26sa%3DN%26tbm%3Disch&ei=G-weTqCYBtDD8QOT-pjUAw|title = Community Health Awareness Programme, Monaragala District General Hospital|publisher= emdtr.org|accessdate=2011-07-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url= http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/pdi.1008/abstract|title = Capacity building through research and educational collaboration: a report of a UK–Sri Lanka collaboration| accessdate=2011-05-28 | doi=10.1002/pdi.1008|volume=23|journal=Practical Diabetes International|pages=350–352}}</ref> helped establish a [[renal dialysis]] unit<ref>{{cite web|url=http://snni.brinkster.net/help/pilisarana.html |title = Dialysis project for Colombo South (Kalubowila) Teaching Hospital, Sri-Lanka|publisher = snni.brinkster.net |accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref> and transit home<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundayleader.lk/archive/20020505/review.htm|title= Transit home and dialysis unit for kidney patients The Sunday Leader 05th May 2002, Volume 8, Issue 42 |publisher=www.thesundayleader.lk |date= |accessdate=2012-11-30}}</ref> for patients and families visiting the University of Sri Jayewardenepura faculty of health sciences and its teaching hospital in 1998;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundayleader.lk/archive/20020505/review.htm |title = Transit home and dialysis unit for kidney patients Sunday Leader 5th May 2002 | publisher= www.thesundayleader.lk |accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref> set up computer servers linking the John Pease Diabetes Centre in [[Sutton-in-Ashfield]], England and centres in Sri Lanka to aid education in Sri Lanka,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moorlands-media.co.uk/docs/pdf/orchid-press-release.pdf|title = Orchid and IBM support Sri Lankan diabetes project| publisher= www.moorlands-media.co.uk |accessdate=2015-08-29}}</ref> and assisted in disaster relief after the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://old.rcplondon.ac.uk/international/Documents/InternationalFocus03.pdf |title = Tsunami Disaster |publisher= rcplondon.ac.uk |accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref>
=={{anchor|Involvement in other notable activity outside academia}}Other activities== Fernando was a school [[Prefect#Academic|prefect]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tyretracks.com/showthread.php?t=505|title= Senior Athletics Meet 1975;Notes and Comments College Magazine Vol.C. No.2- Term 11,1975 |publisher=www.tyretracks.com|date= |accessdate=2011-08-10}}</ref> won awards in rugby and athletics (finished second in the 1973 400m [[Under-20 athletics|junior]] national [[Asian Athletics Association|AAA]] championships),<ref>{{cite web|url= http://tyretracks.com/member.php?u=399|title= Biography|publisher=tyretracks.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://stc-classof74.blogspot.co.uk/2015/10/athletics-team-1972.html|title= Athletics Team 1972|publisher=stx-class of 74.blogspot.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-10-01}}</ref> was active in classical, English debating and drama societies<ref>Rohan Edirisinghe: Those memorable days in the 1970's St Thomas' College Mount Lavinia, in The History of the Old Boys' Association, MD Gunasena &Co 1985 page 172</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tyretracks.com/showthread.php?t=876|title= This Doctor is father of Prof. Devaka Fernando, who had brought great honour and glory to College. In school he was very popular amongst the teachers as an outstanding student. He was also keen Rugby player and athlete. |publisher=www.tyretracks.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref> and was part of the [[rugby union]] [[Royal-Thomian rivalry]]<ref>Ceylon Daily News Lake House Newspapers 12 July 1975</ref><ref>Daily Mirror 12 July 1975</ref> on the 1975 S. Thomas' College team coached by [[Quentin Israel]], called the best Thomian team by sports journalist Sharm de Alwis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tyretracks.com/showthread.php?t=459|title= A Brief overview of Thomian Rugby |publisher=www.tyretracks.com|date= |accessdate=2011-09-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.island.lk/index.php?page_cat=article-details&page=article-details&code_title=88905|title= Thomians honour Quentin Israel by Sharm de Alwis |publisher=www.island.lk|date= |accessdate=2014-02-26}}</ref>
He captained the [[University of Colombo]] rugby team, scoring two [[Try|tries]] in a victory against [[Colombo Hockey and Football Club]];<ref>The Observer Lake House Newspapers Ltd DR Wijewardena Mawate 20 May 1979 page 26</ref> placed second in the 400m hurdles at the 1976 junior national AAA championships, and represented the [[Colombo Hockey and Football Club]] in the 1981 [[Rugby union in Sri Lanka#Schools Rugby League (Singer League)|First Division]] tournament.<ref>Professor Upali Illangasekera President Kandy Society of Medicine: Citation for award of Senaka Bibile Gold Medal, Kandy Society of Medicine 2005</ref> Fernando has coached rugby teams in Sri Lanka and the UK.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thanetccg.nhs.uk/about-us/governing-body/devaka-fernando//|title = Launch of Thanet Clinical Commissioning Group|publisher= www.thanetccg.nhs.uk|accessdate=2013-07-18}}</ref>
==United Kingdom 2005-== Fernando moved to the United Kingdom in 2005, where he has been a consultant endocrinologist, head of the Sherwood Forest Hospitals Foundation Trust's Department of Diabetes and Endocrinology at [[King's Mill Hospital]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sfh-tr.nhs.uk/index.php/healthcare-professionals/find-a-consultant|title = Prof Devaka Fernando|publisher = www.sfh-tr.nhs.uk|accessdate=2013-07-12}}</ref> and a member of the foot-care team,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chad.co.uk/news/health/king-s-mill-hospital-foot-care-team-collect-top-award-1-3291129|title = King’s Mill Hospital foot care team collect top award |publisher = www.sfh-tr.nhs.uk|accessdate=2013-07-12}}</ref> associate medical director for [[clinical governance]]<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.worldofhealthit.org/sessionhandouts/documents/PS28-2-Fernando.pdf|title = Information Technology in Clinical Governance|publisher= www.worldofhealthit.org|accessdate=2011-05-28}}</ref> and member of a trial steering committee.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Tyrer | first1 = P. | display-authors = 1 | last2 = et al | year = | title = Clinical and cost-effectiveness of cognitive behaviour therapy for health anxiety in medical patients: a multicentre randomised controlled trial | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(13)61905-4 | journal = The Lancet | volume = 383| issue = | pages = 219–225}}</ref> In collaboration with the Thyroid Association, he has delivered lectures with colleague George Thomson.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hpth.org.uk/news.php?id=186|title =First Hypoparathyroidism Awareness meeting|publisher= www.btfthyroid.org |accessdate=2011-09-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.btf-thyroid.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=166&Itemid=234|title = Joint BTF and HPTH UK Thyroid/Parathyroid Awareness Meeting |publisher= www.btfthyroid.org |accessdate=2011-09-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisnottingham.co.uk/Professor-talk-thyroid-issues/story-16456006-detail/story.html#axzz2Z0U4H9gt |title =Professor to give talk on thyroid issues|publisher= www.thisisnottingham |accessdate=2013-07-10}}</ref> Fernando is a board member of the [[Thanet District|Thanet]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thanetccg.nhs.uk/about-us/governing-body/devaka-fernando//|title = Launch of Thanet Clinical Commissioning Group|publisher= www.thanetccg.nhs.uk|accessdate=2013-07-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thanetccg.nhs.uk/news/news-child-blog/?blogpost=688|title = Launch of Thanet Clinical Commissioning Group|publisher= www.thanetccg.nhs.uk|accessdate=2013-05-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thanetccg.nhs.uk/news/news-child-blog/?blogpost=688|title = Launch of Thanet Clinical Commissioning Group|publisher= www.thanetccg.nhs.uk|accessdate=2013-05-31}}</ref> and Sheffield [[clinical commissioning group]]s<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sheffieldccg.nhs.uk/Downloads/CCG%20Board%20Papers/September%202015%20Board%20Papers/PAPER%20Aii%20draft%20Public%20minutes%2016.7.15.pdf|title = Minutes of Public meeting|publisher= www.sheffieldccg.nhs.uk|accessdate=2016-03-10}}</ref> and a member of the Diabetes Think Tank, a parliamentary advisory group.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.diabetesthinktank.org.uk/uploads/Diabetes%20Think%20Tank%20-%20Meeting%20Report%20-%20NICE%20clinical%20guidelines.pdf|title = DIABETES THINK TANK NICE: a discussion paper on potential policy recommendations for the Diabetes Think Tank|publisher=www.diabetesthinktank.org.uk |accessdate=2013-05-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.diabetesthinktank.org.uk/|title = The Diabetes Think Tank|publisher=www.diabetesthinktank.org.uk |accessdate=2016-03-31}}</ref>

A '''disease cluster''' is an unusually high incidence of a particular disease or disorder occurring in close proximity in terms of both time and geography.<ref>[http://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/HEC/CSEM/cluster/definition.html "Definition of Clusters"], ''Case Studies in Environmental Medicine (CSEM)'', [[Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry]], [[U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]]</ref> Typically, when clusters are recognized, they are reported to [[public health]] departments in the local area. If clusters are of sufficient size and importance, they may be re-evaluated as [[outbreak]]s. The [[1854 Broad Street cholera outbreak|1854 cholera outbreak]] which occurred in London is a classic example of such a cluster.
==See also== *[[Cancer cluster]] *[[Epidemiology]] *[[Cuzick–Edwards test]] *[[Corby toxic waste case]]

{{lowercase title}} '''eWater''' is a [[Nonprofit organization#Australia|non-profit]] organisation established by Australian Federal and State Governments. The role of eWater is to support integrated [[water resources management]] in Australia through development and implementation of the national hydrological modelling strategy (NHMS).<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.environment.gov.au/minister/archive/farrell/2012/pubs/mr20120529.pdf|title = $4 MILLION TO SUPPORT A NATIONAL HYDROLOGIC MODELLING PLATFORM|date = 29 May 2012|accessdate = 15 July 2014|website = Australian Government - Department of the Environment|publisher = Australian Government|last = Farrell|first = Don}}</ref>
eWater develops and supports a number of software tools for hydrological modelling. Some tools include Source, MUSIC, Rainfall Runoff Library, Stochastic Climate Library and SedNet.
== History ==
In 1992 the CRC for Catchment Hydrology (CRCCH) was formed to produce a decision support system able to predict movement of water, particulates and solutes from land to rivers followed in 1993 by the CRC for Freshwater Ecology (CRCFH).
Model for Urban Stormwater Improvement Conceptualisation (MUSIC) was launched in 2002 Development of The Invisible Modelling Environment (TIME) enabling development and integration of models, which is used by many tools made by eWater
In 2004 the Catchment modelling Toolit was released<ref>[http://www.ewater.com.au/products/ewater-toolkit/catchment-tools/ Catchment Modelling Toolkit]</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url = http://www.mssanz.org.au/MODSIM03/Volume_04/C05/01_Argent.pdf|title = Building a Modelling Toolkit for Prediction of Catchment Behaviour|author1=R.M. Argent |author2=R.A. Vertessy |author3=J.M. Rahman |author4=S.M. Cuddy |author5=G.M. Podger |author6=D.R. Perry |date = 17 July 2003|journal = International Congress on Modelling and Simulation|accessdate = 15 July 2014|doi = }}</ref>
eWater Ltd was established in 2005 and CRCFE and CRCCH were merged and relaunched as eWater CRC
eWater CRC ends and eWater Ltd continues as a non-profit organisation
Minister for the Environment Senator Penny Wong announces eWater Source as the new COAG endorsed National Hydrological Platform and in 2014 the Source Public modelling tool is launched as a free software package
== Source == '''Source,''' an integrated water resource management modelling tool, developed by eWater Ltd is used to create hydrological models used for integrated planning, management and operations for catchment and river systems, including demands fore water from urban areas, agriculture and the environment
The package has been used to build river and catchment models in every state of Australia as well as many other countries including India,<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://aid.dfat.gov.au/LatestNews/Pages/Australia-and-India-partner-to-manage-water-for-scarcity.aspx|title = Australia and India partner to manage water for scarcity|date = 26 April 2013|accessdate = 15 July 2014|website = Australian Government - Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade|publisher = Australian Government}}</ref> Pakistan, China and the Mekong<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://aid.dfat.gov.au/Publications/Documents/mekongwater-appr-2012-13.pdf,|title = Aid Program Performance Report 2012−13 Australian Mekong Water Resources Program|date = |accessdate = 15 July 2014|website = Australian Government - Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade|publisher = Australian Government}}</ref> River system
The [[Murray-Darling Basin Authority|MDBA]]''' ''' has implemented a Source management model of the Murray and Lower Darling River System.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.mdba.gov.au/what-we-do/managing-rivers/hydrological-modelling|title = Hydrological Modelling using eWater's Source|date = |accessdate = 15 July 2014|website = Australian Government - Murray Darling Basin Authority|publisher = Australian Government}}</ref>
The Queensland Government is now working with Source in five river basins: the Pioneer, Fitzroy, Condamine-Balonne, Cape, and Flinders and Gilbert. Over 30 earlier catchment Source models were implemented under the Great Barrier Reef Action Plan<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.reefplan.qld.gov.au/measuring-success/methods/assets/gbr-report-card-2011-pollutant-loads-methods.pdf|title = Great Barrier Reef Report Card 2011|date = 2011|accessdate = 15 July 2014|website = Reef Water Quality Protection Plan|publisher = Australian Government, Queensland Government}}</ref>
New South Wales is implementing the Namoi River System<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.environment.gov.au/resource/environmental-water-delivery-namoi-river|title = Environmental water delivery: Namoi River|date = |accessdate = 15 July 2014|website = Department of Environment|publisher = Commonwealth Environmental Water Office, Australian Government}}</ref> and Murrimbidgee river system using Source.
Victoria is implementing the Loddon, Campaspe, Broken and Coliban components of a broader northern Victoria Source model centred on the Goulburn River system.
== TIME (The Invisible Modelling Environment) == The Invisible Modelling Environment (TIME) is a software development framework for creating, testing and delivering [[environmental simulation]] models. TIME includes support for the representation, management and visualisation of a variety of data types, as well as support for testing, integrating and calibrating simulation models.
TIME provides a framework for spatial and temporal data analysis. TIME has been developed under the sponsorship of eWater CRC and its predecessor CRC for Catchment Hydrology. As well as providing a modelling framework, TIME supports model users with a range of data analysis and management, model processing and visualisation tools.
TIME is a core component of a large range of formal software products, as well as numerous research programs. Currently the TIME code base is incorporated into approximately 23 eWater supported applications.
The eWater Source products are a major focus of this product range and are extensively used by government and private enterprise in addressing water quantity and quality policy questions.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://publications.csiro.au/rpr/download?pid=csiro:EP127296&dsid=DS5|title = Review of The Invisible Modelling Environment (TIME)|date = 15 December 2012|accessdate = 15 July 2014|website = CSIRO Research Publications Repository|publisher = CSIRO|author1=Ross Searle |author2=David Penton }}</ref> Time is also integrated into a range of [[Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation|CSIRO]] specific products and projects such as the “[http://www.csiro.au/Organisation-Structure/Flagships/Water-for-a-Healthy-Country-Flagship/Integrated-Water-Resources-Management/Hydrologists-workbench_CLW_Project.aspx Hydrologists Workbench]” and the [http://www.bom.gov.au/water/awra/ Australian Water Resources Assessment (AWRA)] system, a continental water balance monitoring system that is being developed jointly by CSIRO and the Bureau of Meteorology.
== eWater Toolkit == The eWater Toolkit is a source of software tools and information related to the modelling and management of water resources, including [[Water quality modelling|water quality]] tools. It provides a web-based distribution point for hydrological, ecological and catchment management models, databases and other resources.
== MUSIC == MUSIC predicts the performance of stormwater quality management systems as an aid to decision-making. It is intended to help organisations [[Urban planning in Australia|plan]] and design (at a conceptual level) appropriate urban stormwater management systems for their catchments that meet [[Water-sensitive urban design|Water Sensitive Urban Design]] Standards

{{short description|Management and technical processes required to provide sanitation in emergency situations}} [[File:Raised toilet in Haiti (7281252188).jpg|thumb|Emergency [[toilet]] in [[Haiti]], suitable for areas where digging [[Pit latrine|pit latrines]] is not possible]]
'''Emergency sanitation''' is the management and technical processes required to provide [[sanitation]] in [[emergency]] situations. This can include man-made or [[Natural disaster|natural disasters]]. Emergency sanitation is also required during [[Humanitarian aid|humanitarian relief]] operations for [[Refugee|refugees]] and [[Internally displaced person|Internally Displaced Persons]] (IDPs).
Emergency situations are classified into three phases which are called the "immediate", "short-term" and "long-term" phases. In the immediate phase, the focus is on reducing [[open defecation]]. Toilets provided might include very basic [[Latrine|latrines]], [[pit latrines]], [[Bucket toilet|bucket toilets,]] [[Container-based sanitation|container-based toilets]] or [[Chemical toilet|chemical toilets]].
Providing showers and [[Hand washing|handwashing]] facilities is also part of emergency sanitation during all phases. [[Fecal sludge management|Fecal sludge management]] becomes a priority during the long-term emergency management phase.
== Background== The term "[[Emergency]]" is perceived differently by different people and organisations. In a general sense, an emergency may be considered to be a phenomenon originating from a man-made and/or [[natural disaster]] which results in a serious, usually sudden threat to the health or well-being of the affected community which relies on external assistance to easily cope up with the situation.<ref name="Harveybook" />
There are different categories of emergency depending on its time frame, whether it lasts for few weeks, several months or years.<ref name="Harveybook">{{cite book|url=http://www.susana.org/en/resources/library/details/359|title=Excreta disposal in emergencies a field manual : an inter-agency publication|date=2007|publisher=Loughborough university. Water, engineering and development centre (WEDC)|year=|isbn=9781843801139|location=Loughborough|pages=250|last1=Peter Harvey|first1=with contrib. from Andy Bastable...[et al.]}}</ref>
The number of people who are and will be affected by catastrophes (human crisis and natural disasters), which are increasing in magnitude and frequency, is rapidly increasing. The affected people are subjected to such dangers as temporary homelessness and risks to life and health.<ref>BORDA (2010). [http://www.susana.org/en/resources/library/details/1508 EmSan - Emergency Sanitation - An innovative & rapidly applicable solution to safeguard hygiene and health in emergency situations]. Bremen Overseas Research and Development Association (BORDA) & BORDA BNS Network</ref>
== Methods == [[File:Emergencysan unhcr.jpg|alt=Emergency pit latrines|thumb|Emergency pit latrines with bathing shelters built in the [[Bidi Bidi Refugee Settlement|Bidi Bidi refugee settlement]] in northern [[Uganda]] ]] To address the problem of [[public health]] and the spread of dangerous diseases that come as a result of lack of [[sanitation]] and [[open defecation]], humanitarian actors focus on the construction of, for example, [[pit latrines]] and the implementation of [[hygiene]] promotion programmes.<ref name="Grange">Grange, C. (2016). [http://www.susana.org/en/resources/library/details/2455 Faecal Sludge Management - WASH in Emergencies, Problem Exploration Report]. HIF (Humanitarian Innovation Fund) Problem Exploration Report. Cardiff: ELRHA</ref>
The supply of [[drinking water]] in an urban-setting emergency has been improved by the introduction of standardised, rapid deployment kits.
In the immediate emergency phase, the focus is on managing open defecation, and toilet technologies might include very basic [[Latrine#Trench latrine|trench latrines]], [[pit latrines]], [[Bucket toilet|bucket toilets,]] [[Container-based sanitation|container-based toilets]], [[Chemical toilet|chemical toilets]]. The short term phase might also involve technologies such as [[urine-diverting dry toilets]], [[Septic tank|septic tanks]], [[Decentralized wastewater system|decentralized wastewater systems]].
In urban emergencies, the main focus is usually on a quick rehabilitation and extension of existing services such as [[Sanitary sewer|sewer-lines]] and [[Sewage treatment|waste-water treatment plants]]. This can also include the installation of [[Sewage pumping|sewerage pumping]] stations to improve or extend services.
== Settings == {{Unreferenced section|date=October 2017}} The emergency response often has to differ greatly based on the setting it takes place.
=== Home based === Home based settings where people choose to stay in or close to their homes (or those of their relatives, neighbours or friends). While this setting offers the quickest way to (self-) recovery, it also poses a high risk of sanitation related impacts due to the common lack of access to outside help and inadequate public-health monitoring.
=== Host community === Host community settings with significant displacement into outside communities (usually [[Urban area|urban]]) with existing but maybe also effected sanitation infrastructure in private homes.
Existing infrastructure in such settings is usually quickly overloaded due to the increase in population density and improvements/repair is often hindered by access- and space-limitations. Intra-community conflicts over the sanitation waste management are thus fairly common.
=== Mass shelter === Mass shelter settings where the displaced population is housed in existing but often re-purposed building-complexes such as [[schools]], [[community centres]], [[places of worship]], [[Shopping mall|malls]], [[Warehouse|warehouses]] and [[Stadium|sport stadiums]]. In some disaster prone countries, dedicated large [[Emergency shelter|emergency shelters]] are build for this purpose.
Existing sanitation facilities are usually inadequate for full-time stay of a high number of people, and the non-emergency management structures are typically unable or unwilling to continue their services. Legal issues over the re-purposing are also fairly common, especially if occupation continues for a longer time.
Due to usually cramped living conditions there is a high risk of conflict and often also cases of sexual violence, both of which often are in some relation to the sanitation facilities.
=== Emergency settlements === Emergency settlements (formal or informal) where previously sparsely populated areas are newly occupied by the displaced population in large numbers. Typically these are set up by governments, the [[United Nations|UN]] and [[humanitarian aid]] organisations.
Due to the typically short time frame of arrivals and the non-existing infrastructure, these kind of encampments pose maybe the greatest challenge in regards to providing adequate emergency sanitation facilities.
== Challenges == [[File:Emergency pit lining kits by Evenproducts (6619616743).jpg|thumb|Emergency pit lining kits, suitable for areas with high water table]] The provision of sanitation programmes is usually more challenging than [[water supply]] as it provides a limited choice of technologies.<ref name="Grange" /><ref name="Briantj">{{Cite web|url=http://www.urban-response.org/resource/19245|title=Urban Humanitarian Response Portal|website=urban-response.org|access-date=2017-04-19}}</ref> This is exacerbated by the overwhelming and diverse needs of [[WASH]].<ref name="Briantj" />
Challenges with excreta disposal in emergencies include: * Building [[Latrines]] in areas where pits cannot be dug, desludging latrines, no-toilet options and the final treatment or disposal of the [[Fecal sludge management|fecal sludge]].<ref name="Bastable">Bastable, A., Russell, L. (2013). [http://www.susana.org/en/resources/library/details/2452 Gap Analysis in Emergency Water, Sanitation and Hygiene Promotion]. Humanitarian Innovation Fund (HIF), London, UK</ref> * Weak community participation and finding hygiene promotion designs that are suitable for a given context to make the WASH interventions sustainable. * Newly arriving [[Internally displaced person|IDP]] or [[refugee]] populations can usually only be settled in less than ideal areas, such as land that is prone to regular flooding or which is very dry and with rocky ground.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} This makes the provision of safe sanitation facilities and other infrastructure very difficult. * In long running emergencies, the safe decommissioning or desludging of previously quickly built sanitation facilities can also become a serious challenge.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} * [[Humanitarian aid|Humanitarian actors]] need to understand the importance of better preparation and [[Resilience (engineering and construction)|resilience]] and the need for exit strategies and have consideration on the environment.<ref name="Bastable" />
== See also == * [[Self-supply of water and sanitation]]

{{Infobox nonhuman protein | Name = Enterotoxin type B | image = | width = | caption = | Organism = Staphylococcus aureus | TaxID = 1280 | Symbol = entB | AltSymbols = | IUPHAR_id = | ATC_prefix = | ATC_suffix = | ATC_supplemental = | CAS_number = | CAS_supplemental = | DrugBank = | EntrezGene = | PDB = | RefSeqmRNA = | RefSeqProtein = | UniProt = P01552 | ECnumber = | Chromosome = | EntrezChromosome = | GenLoc_start = | GenLoc_end = }} {{Infobox protein family | Symbol = Staphylococcal/Streptococcal toxin, N-terminal domain | Name = Staphylococcal/Streptococcal toxin, N-terminal domain | image = PDB 1eu4 EBI.jpg | width = | caption = Crystal structure of the superantigen Spe-H (zinc bound) from ''Streptococcus pyogenes'' | Pfam = PF01123 | Pfam_clan = | InterPro = IPR006173 | SMART = | PROSITE = PDOC00250 | MEROPS = | SCOP = 1se3 | TCDB = | OPM family = | OPM protein = | CAZy = | CDD = }} {{Pfam_box | Symbol = Stap_Strp_tox_C | Name = Staphylococcal/Streptococcal toxin, beta-grasp domain | image = | width = | caption = | Pfam= PF02876 | InterPro= IPR006123 | SMART= | Prosite = PDOC00250 | SCOP = 1se3 | TCDB = | OPM family= | OPM protein= }} In the field of [[molecular biology]], '''enterotoxin type B''', also known as '''Staphylococcal enterotoxin B''' ('''SEB'''), is an [[enterotoxin]] produced by the [[gram-positive]] [[bacteria]] ''[[Staphylococcus aureus]]''. It is a common cause of [[food poisoning]], with severe [[diarrhea]], [[nausea]] and intestinal cramping often starting within a few hours of ingestion.<ref name="emedicine">{{cite web |url=http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/830715-overview|title=eMedicine - CBRNE - Staphylococcal Enterotoxin B|format= |work=eMedicine|accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> Being quite stable,<ref name="pmid17477998">{{cite journal |vauthors=Nema V, Agrawal R, Kamboj DV, Goel AK, Singh L | title = Isolation and characterization of heat resistant enterotoxigenic Staphylococcus aureus from a food poisoning outbreak in Indian subcontinent | journal = Int. J. Food Microbiol. | volume = 117 | issue = 1 | pages = 29–35 |date=June 2007 | pmid = 17477998 | doi = 10.1016/j.ijfoodmicro.2007.01.015 }}</ref> the toxin may remain active even after the contaminating bacteria are killed. It can withstand boiling at 100 °C for a few minutes.<ref name="emedicine" /> [[Gastroenteritis]] occurs because SEB is a [[superantigen]], causing the immune system to release a large amount of [[cytokine]]s that lead to significant inflammation.
Additionally, this protein is one of the causative agents of [[toxic shock syndrome]].
== Function==
The function of this protein is to facilitate the infection of the [[host (biology)|host]] organism. It is a [[virulence factor]] designed to induce [[pathogenesis]].<ref name="pmid3782090">{{cite journal |vauthors=Blomster-Hautamaa DA, Kreiswirth BN, Kornblum JS, Novick RP, Schlievert PM | title = The nucleotide and partial amino acid sequence of toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 | journal = J. Biol. Chem. | volume = 261 | issue = 33 | pages = 15783–6 |date=November 1986 | pmid = 3782090 | doi = }}</ref> One of the major virulence [[exotoxins]] is the [[toxic shock syndrome]] [[toxin]] (TSST), which is [[secreted]] by the [[organism]] upon successful [[infection|invasion]]. It causes a major [[Inflammation|inflammatory response]] in the host via [[superantigen]]ic properties, and is the causative agent of toxic shock syndrome. It functions as a superantigen through activation of a significant fraction of [[T-cell]]s (up to 20%) by cross-linking [[MHC class II]] molecules with [[T-cell receptor]]s. TSST is a multisystem illness with several [[symptoms]] such as high [[fever]], [[hypotension]], dizziness, rash and peeling skin.<ref name="pmid3782090" />
== Structure ==
All of these toxins share a similar two-domain fold (N and C-terminal domains) with a long alpha-helix in the middle of the molecule, a characteristic beta-barrel known as the "oligosaccharide/oligonucleotide fold" at the N-terminal domain and a beta-grasp motif at the C-terminal domain. Each superantigen possesses slightly different binding mode(s) when it interacts with MHC class II molecules or the T-cell receptor.<ref name="PUB00007937">{{cite journal |vauthors=Acharya KR, Papageorgiou AC, Tranter HS |title=Crystal structure of microbial superantigen staphylococcal enterotoxin B at 1.5 A resolution: implications for superantigen recognition by MHC class II molecules and T-cell receptors |journal=J. Mol. Biol. |volume=277 |issue=1 |pages=61–79 |year=1998 |pmid=9514739 |doi=10.1006/jmbi.1997.1577}}</ref>
=== N-terminal domain ===
The [[N-terminal]] domain is also referred to as OB-fold, or in other words the oligonuclucleotide binding fold. This region contains a low-affinity major histocompatibility complex class II ([[MHC II]]) site which causes an [[Inflammation|inflammatory response]].<ref name="pmid21535475">{{cite journal |vauthors=Brosnahan AJ, Schlievert PM |title=Gram-positive bacterial superantigen outside-in signaling causes toxic shock syndrome |journal=FEBS J. |volume=278 |issue=23 |pages=4649–67 |date=December 2011 |pmid=21535475 |doi=10.1111/j.1742-4658.2011.08151.x |url= |pmc=3165073}}</ref>
The N-terminal [[protein domain|domain]] contains regions involved in Major Histocompatibility Complex class II association. It is a five stranded [[beta barrel]] that forms an OB fold.<ref name="pmid8268150">{{cite journal |vauthors=Prasad GS, Earhart CA, Murray DL, Novick RP, Schlievert PM, Ohlendorf DH | title = Structure of toxic shock syndrome toxin 1 | journal = Biochemistry | volume = 32 | issue = 50 | pages = 13761–6 |date=December 1993 | pmid = 8268150 | doi = 10.1021/bi00213a001}}</ref><ref name="pmid8107781">{{cite journal |vauthors=Acharya KR, Passalacqua EF, Jones EY, Harlos K, Stuart DI, Brehm RD, Tranter HS | title = Structural basis of superantigen action inferred from crystal structure of toxic-shock syndrome toxin-1 | journal = Nature | volume = 367 | issue = 6458 | pages = 94–7 |date=January 1994 | pmid = 8107781 | doi = 10.1038/367094a0 }}</ref><ref name="pmid9194182">{{cite journal |vauthors=Prasad GS, Radhakrishnan R, Mitchell DT, Earhart CA, Dinges MM, Cook WJ, Schlievert PM, Ohlendorf DH | title = Refined structures of three crystal forms of toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 and of a tetramutant with reduced activity | journal = Protein Sci. | volume = 6 | issue = 6 | pages = 1220–7 |date=June 1997 | pmid = 9194182 | pmc = 2143723 | doi = 10.1002/pro.5560060610 }}</ref>
=== C-terminal domain ===
The beta-grasp domain has some structural similarities to the beta-grasp motif present in immunoglobulin-binding domains, ubiquitin, 2Fe-2 S ferredoxin and translation initiation factor 3 as identified by the SCOP database.

{{single source|date=December 2009}} [[File:Gefriersperma.JPG|250px|right|thumb|[[Ampule]]s of frozen bovine semen in [[liquid nitrogen]] canister]] '''Frozen bovine semen''' is a method of preserving bovine [[semen]] for future [[artificial insemination]], even after the death of the donor.
==History== The early artificial insemination organizations were largely farmer-owned cooperatives. The first such cooperative in America was organized at [[Clinton, New Jersey|Clinton]], [[New Jersey]], through efforts of Enos J. Perry, Extension Dairyman, [[New Brunswick, New Jersey|New Brunswick]], and began operations May 17, 1938. It began operations with 102 members and 1,050 cows enrolled.
Using [[frozen semen]] for dairy [[cattle]] has been done since the 1950s. The oldest semen believed to be in existence was from a sire named Cottonade Emmet, who was a member of the [[American Breeders Service]] sire battery in 1952. Semen [[semen collection|was collected]] on Emmet in November 1952 and has been used several times to produce [[offspring]]. However, the last time any such offspring was born was in the mid-1980s. Osborndale Ivanhoe, who was probably the most famous [[Holstein]] bull of the early semen era, died in November 1963. From time to time [[calf|calves]] will still be born from his frozen semen. Ivanhoe was a member of The Atlantic Breeder's Co-op Sire battery. His sons who have had considerable influence include, Penstate Ivanhoe Star, Provin Mtn Ivanhoe Jewel, and Fleetridge Monitor. His grandsons who have dominated the Holstein breed include Carlin-M Ivanhoe Bell, and Round Oak Rag Apple Elevation.
==Types of semen packaging== {{expand with relevant sources|1=https://www.google.com/#q=cattle+%22semen+packaging%22|date=December 2013}} Semen in the early days of artificial insemination was delivered everyday to technicians by bull [[stud (animal)|stud]]s as semen was not frozen at this point. It was not until the addition of [[glycerol]] to [[semen extender]]s that semen could be frozen. In those early days semen was extended by bulls stud into a type of bottle, or [[test tube]], kept at low temperatures, and delivered to technicians usually everyday. The freezing process was discovered by a man named Polge. It was placed in containers called glass [[ampule]]s, sealed, frozen in [[dry ice]] and alcohol and kept in that type of solution until it was needed for insemination. Later the [[liquid nitrogen]] refrigerator was invented by [[Union Carbide]] with money given to them by [[John Rockefeller Prentice]], who used it exclusively for his bull stud before a number of years later giving it to the entire artificial insemination (A.I.) industry at no charge or royalty. Liquid nitrogen boils at −195.79 °C (77 K; −320 °F), which allows very little deterioration of bovine semen. The ampules were fastened to a cane which was placed inside the canister. The process of insemination involves transferring the ampule to an water/ice bath. The ampule thaws for several minutes and when opened, the semen is drawn up into a [[pipette]].
Other semen packages that have been tried include the "Magic Wand" developed by Badger Breeders Co-op in the mid-1960s. This was a frozen pipette that contained about .75 cc of extended semen. With the use of a connector and adapter which had a syringe or rubber bulb attached it was air thawed or thawed in the cow. The frozen polybulb was another semen package that had some usage. Semen was actually placed in a plastic polybulb and frozen on canes. The polybulb was thawed, sealed end cut, and attached to a pipette. The semen expelled through the pipette. There were several size of ampules used during the early days. The 1cc ampules were used by Curtiss Breeding Service, .75cc ampules were used by Tri-State Breeders Co-op, and the .50cc ampules were almost excursively used by American Breeders Service. The .75 and 1cc ampules were usually attached six to a metal cane. The .50 cc ampules were attached eight per cane.
===Plastic straw packaging=== In the 1960s a straw package that utilized a plastic straw was invented by the Robert Cassou family business called IMV in France. This straw was made of PVC and had two cotton plugs with powder in between them (the "factory end") while the other end was open. Semen was sucked up into the straw and was placed directly onto a comb and semen was expelled to make an airspace. Then the straw was placed directly into a pile of PVC powder that sealed the straw. Then the straw was placed into a water bath for a period of time to plug the end sealed. Then dried with cloth towels and frozen on metal racks. After freezing the straws were placed in 95 °F water and thawed for 60 seconds before being placed into a stainless steel gun. A sheath was placed over the gun and locked into place by an o-ring. Then the cow was inseminated the usual way.
In the early 1970s an automated machine was invented by IMV. This machine would seal the straws ([[ultrasound|ultrasonically]]) one by one. Then several years later a machine that would fill and seal straws three at a time came out. This greatly increased processing times for bull studs. In the mid-2000s a machine that would not only fill three straws at a time but also have the capability to print the desired information on the straw, became available.
==How semen is collected== {{refimprove section|date=June 2014}} Bull semen can be collected by using an [[artificial vagina]] (AV), [[electro-ejaculator]], or by massaging the ampule of the bull by hand.
===Preparation of the AV=== The most desired use is the AV. The AV is made up of a piece of heavy rubber hose about {{convert|5|cm|abbr=on}} in diameter and up a {{convert|18|in|cm|abbr=on|disp=flip}} or more (in some cases less) in length. A small screw cap attachment is fitted or drilled preferably in the middle of the housing. A piece of [[latex]] or [[silicone rubber]] (usually rough inside, but some cases smooth) then is put through the hose and pulled up at both ends. Another latex or silicone cone shaped attachment is placed on one end of the AV an held by a rubber band. on thee end of the cone a glass or plastic centrifudge tube is attached usually 15ml size). Through the cap attachment water usually around 54°C is filled until the AV is 1/2 full (temperature may vary from bull to bull). This water is between the inside rubber and the inside hose wall of the AV. A small amount of [[K-Y jelly]] or [[Vaseline]] is placed just inside on the unconed end and then it is smeared with a pipette or greasing stick. Finally in most cases and AV jacket is tied or attached onto the cone end to cover the cone and tube. This will help prevent cold shock to the semen by keeping the cone and tube warm. The collector then goes cautiously to the side of the bull when he is in mount, directs the [[bull's penis]] inside the AV by grabbing the [[penile sheath|sheath]] directly behind the extended penis (never touching the penis itself). The bull then ejaculates after his penis slides through the AV. The bull should be ejaculating through the AV into the cone of the AV so there is very little chance of temperature shock to the semen. after the bull has dismounted the AV should be held in the upright position so the semen runs into the tube onto the end of the cone. Then the tube is detached and placed upright in a water bath of about 29-32°C.
===Preparation of the bull=== In a commercially or Custom Stud a bull is generally brought to a collection area where there are gates or other protection areas set up. In most cases of Dairy Bulls the bull has a halter or rope inserted into his nose ring. This is so he can be led and his handler can be a safe distance away, yet have some control over the animal. In the collection area there usually is a stall or stanchion where a mount animal is tied in. A mount animal can be a steer, a cow, or even another bull. Some bulls can be rather aggressive and have no problems or issues mounting another animal. Others are rather passive and may show little or no interest in mounting. Different scenarios are used to try to entice him to mount. Such scenarios may include a different breed of steer, a different bull, or even a cow. Sometimes a bull may be wary of the individual who is approaching him to collect. In which cases a blindfold may have to be put over his eye in that side. The bull mounts and semen is able to be collected as the bull doesn't worry about what is going on.
===Collection on farm=== A number of bulls are not collected in commercial or stud setups. These bulls may not be good enough to enter active AI service. However the owner may only elect to use him a small amount in his own herd or perhaps a syndicate may want to control the amount of breedings or services to him. In this case the bull may be sent to a custom stud or be collected on farm. The owner may elect to only collect a few hundred to several thousand units (straws) on the bull. In most of the custom studs the semen can be stored and sent out to other breeders. In some cases where there is not a significant population of females in a particular breed, a bull may have a designated supply of semen collected and then be sent to slaughter. However a bank or supply of his semen is kept in storage for many years, still breeding females for many years after he has departed.
While many beef bulls are collected in stud a good share are collected on farm or in custom studs. Many of the bulls will be used in the owners' herds during beef breeding season. However they have the genetic merit to be used in many others as well. A beef bull may only be able to service 20 to 30 head via natural service during the breeding season. He will be able to service many more during the breeding season via artificial insemination. If he becomes hurt, disabled, or even dies, he can still sire hundreds or thousands of progeny.
