Russell Medal, Markle Scholars, 1971; Martin E. Rehfuss Medal and Lectureship; Johns Hopkins University Alumni Association Award, 1999; Lifetime Achievement Award "For Fearlessly Promoting the Rights of All to Health Care", Health Care, 2000; Adam Yarmolinsky Medal, Institute of Medicine, 2000; Debs-Thomas-Bernstein Awards, 2009 | memorials = | spouse = Ruth (Breslau) Fein | signature = | module = | repec_prefix = | repec_id = }} '''Rashi Fein''' (February 6, 1926 – September 8, 2014) was an American [[health economics|health economist]] termed "a father of Medicare" in the United States[http://www.jta.org/2014/09/09/news-opinion/united-states/rashi-fein-a-father-of-medicare-dies Rashi Fein, a "father of Medicare," dies, September 9, 2014, 11:52am, in ''JTA''] and "an architect of Medicare,"{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2014/09/10/rashi-fein-harvard-economist-was-architect-medicare-and-advocate-for-universal-health-care/4i5PRItWabE6YKcHXRncqO/story.html?s_campaign=email_BG_TodaysHeadline|title=Rashi Fein, 88; Harvard economist was an architect of Medicare and an advocate for universal health care - The Boston Globe|website=bostonglobe.com}} was Professor of Economics of Medicine, Emeritus, in the Department of Global Health and Social Medicine at [[Harvard Medical School]], and the author of the book ''Medical Care, Medical Costs: The Search for a Health Insurance Policy''{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Medical-Care-Costs-Search-Insurance/dp/1583483101|title=Medical Care, Medical Costs: The Search for a Health Insurance Policy|first=Rashi|last=Fein|date=21 June 1999|publisher=iUniverse|via=Amazon}} ([[Harvard University Press]], 1986, 1989).{{cite web|url=http://ghsm.hms.harvard.edu/people/faculty/rashi-fein|title=Department of Global Health & Social Medicine|last=|first=|date=|website=ghsm.hms.harvard.edu|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ptZwCVvIJxkC&q=%22fein,+rashi%22+1926&dq=%22fein,+rashi%22+1926&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ak0QVNrUAc-cygSon4LoDg&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAjgK|title=The International Who's who: 1990-91|last=Limited|first=Europa Publications|date=17 April 1990|website=|publisher=Europa Publications Limited|page=491|via=Google Books|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} His work has included [[benefit-cost analysis]], [[Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services|health care financing]], [[health workforce|health care workforce policy]], [[health equity]], [[Health maintenance organization#cost containment|cost containment]], the [[Medicare (United States)#Graduate Medical Education|financing]] of [[medical education]], and [[health care reform]]. He was the brother of [[Leonard Fein|Leonard J. Fein]], also known as Leibel Fein, an American activist and writer, who had taught [[political science]] at [[MIT]], became Deputy Director of the [[Harvard–MIT Joint Center for Urban Studies]], and specialized in [[Jewish]] social themes.{{cite web|url=http://mazon.org/2010/10/26/a-brothers-tribute-to-leonard-fein/|title=A brother’s tribute to Leonard Fein|website=MAZON: A Jewish Response to Hunger}} Fein served on the Advisory Committee of the Jewish Alliance for Law and Social Action He died of [[melanoma]] at [[Massachusetts General Hospital]], in Boston.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/14/us/rashi-fein-economist-who-urged-medicare-dies-at-88.html|title=Rashi Fein, Economist Who Urged Medicare, Dies at 88|first=Douglas|last=Martin|date=13 September 2014|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}} ==Career== He began his service to the [[United States]] during [[World War II]] in the [[US Navy]].{{cite web|url=http://keywiki.org/Rashi_Fein|title=Rashi Fein - KeyWiki|website=keywiki.org}} He spent much of his time after that thinking and writing about [[health care reform]]. He was a member of the [[Truman Committee|Truman Commission on the Health Care Needs of the Nation]], which, as early as 1952, had supported [[national health insurance]] and the regionalization of [[health care delivery]]. Later, he served on President [[John F. Kennedy]]'s [[Council of Economic Advisors]] as a senior staff member (1961-1963). There, he helped to develop the initial legislation for [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]], a healthcare model that he continued to advocate throughout his life.{{cite web|url=http://www.socialsecurity.gov/history/ssa/lbjexternal3.html|title=Social Security History|website=www.socialsecurity.gov}}{{cite web|url=http://www.socialsecurity.gov/history/archives/cohenguide.htm|title=Papers of Wilbur J. Cohen, notes Rashi Fein's role as member of the Advisory Council on Research Development, which provided assistance to the Social Security Administration for its research program|website=socialsecurity.gov}} Fein had also served on the Board of the Committee for National Health Insurance, under the leadership of former [[United Auto Workers]] President [[Douglas Fraser]] and under [[Walter Reuther]] on a board investigating [[malnutrition]] in the United States.{{cite web|url=https://kaiserfamilyfoundation.files.wordpress.com/2013/01/7871.pdf|title=National Health Insurance—A Brief History of Reform Efforts in the U.S., March 2009, in Focus on Health Reform, blog of the Henry K. Kaiser Family Foundation|website=wordpress.com}}[http://www.reuther.wayne.edu/files/LR001069.pdf Index of Archives of Committee for National Health Insurance Collection in the Walter P. Reuther Library of Wayne State University] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170405002645/http://reuther.wayne.edu/files/LR001069.pdf |date=2017-04-05 }} He was a charter member of the [[Institute of Medicine]] (IOM), had received numerous honors for service in [[medical economics]], and sat on boards of a number of not-for-profit health care institutions. He had authored nine books, the most recent of which was ''Lessons Learned: Medicine, Economics and Public Policy'',{{cite journal|last=Anderson|first=Gerald F.|date=22 September 2010|title=Learning Lessons: Medicine, Economics, and Public Policy|url=http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=186595|journal=JAMA|volume=304|issue=12|pages=|doi=10.1001/jama.2010.1380|via=jamanetwork.com|website=}} published in November 2009.[http://healthpolicyscholars.org/rashi-fein Profile Page for Rashi Fein, Scholars in Health Policy Research, Robert Wood Johnson] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140910195154/http://healthpolicyscholars.org/rashi-fein |date=2014-09-10 }} He joined the Harvard faculty of the [[Harvard Medical School|school of medicine]] and the [[John F. Kennedy School of Government]] in 1968. He also served as senior fellow in the [[economics]] program at the [[Brookings Institution]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] His 1982 paper "What Is Wrong with the Language of Medicine?"{{cite journal|url=https://doi.org/10.1056/NEJM198204083061409|title=What Is Wrong with the Language of Medicine?|first=Rashi|last=Fein|date=8 April 1982|publisher=|journal=New England Journal of Medicine|volume=306|issue=14|pages=863–864|via=Taylor and Francis+NEJM|doi=10.1056/NEJM198204083061409|pmid=7062966}} in the ''[[New England Journal of Medicine]]'' began:
A new language is infecting the culture of American medicine. It is the language of the marketplace, of the tradesman, and of the cost accountant. It is a language that depersonalizes both patients and physicians and describes medical care as just another commodity. It is a language that is dangerous.
It concluded:
A decent medical-care system that helps all the people cannot be built without the language of equity and care. If this language is permitted to die and is completely replaced by the language of efficiency and cost control, all of us — including physicians — will lose something precious.
He served as chair of the National Advisory Committee (NAC) for the [[Robert Wood Johnson Foundation]]'s Scholars in Health Policy Research Program from 1994 to 2002 and was its Chair Emeritus until his death. His work included [[benefit-cost analysis]], [[Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services|health care financing]], [[health workforce|health care workforce policy]], [[Health maintenance organization#cost containment|cost containment]], the [[Medicare (United States)#Graduate Medical Education|financing]] of [[medical education]], and [[health care reform]]. His first book was ''Economics of Mental Illness'' (1958). His last (2010) book, ''Lessons Learned: Medicine, Economics and Public Policy'', was built on the various lessons and stories that, as Chair of the NAC, he had presented over the years at the Scholars’ Annual Meeting in Aspen. As an invited speaker, he presented his soon-to-be-piblished book at the "Health Care Reform 2009: Politics and Paranoia" in [[Boston]] on October 21, 2009, sponsored by the Boston [[Democratic Socialists of America]] and Mass-Care.{{cite web|url=http://openmediaboston.org/content/health-care-reform-2009-politics-and-paranoia|title=Health Care Reform 2009: Politics and Paranoia - Open Media Boston|website=openmediaboston.org}} Among colleagues, Fein was admired for his wry, often-humorous [[anecdotes]] drawn from [[Jewish culture]] and over 50 years of experience in the policy arena, which he brought together in his final book, ''Learning Lessons: Medicine, Economics, and Public Policy'' (Transaction Publishers, 2010). He also had served as a Director at Newbridge on the Charles, a senior living facility, an affiliate of the [[Harvard Medical School]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hebrewseniorlife.org/newbridge-leadership-team|title=The NewBridge Leadership Team - Here for You - NewBridge on the Charles|website=www.hebrewseniorlife.org}}{{cite web|url=http://people.equilar.com/bio/newbridge-on/school/23062#.VA9DiYbF-2d|title=NEWBRIDGE ON THE CHARLES INC - Alumni and Associates - Equilar BoardEdge|website=people.equilar.com}} ==Achievements== ===Education=== * B.A., [[Johns Hopkins University]], Baltimore, MD (1948) * Ph.D. ([[political economy]]), [[Johns Hopkins University]], Baltimore, MD (1956) * M.A., [[Harvard University]] (1976) * (Hon) D. Litt., [[State University of New York]] (1996){{cite web|url=http://www.albany.edu/academics/honorary.degree.shtml|title=University at Albany - SUNY Honorary Degrees|first=Sairam|last=Chinnam|website=www.albany.edu}} ===Professional and academic career=== * Staff, President [[Harry S. Truman]]'s [[Presidential Commission (United States)|Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation]], 1952 * Lecturer to Associate Professor, [[Economics]] Department, [[University of North Carolina]], [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill|Chapel Hill]], 1952-1961 * Project Director, Economics of [[Mental Illness]], [[M. Brewster Smith#Joint Commission on Mental Illness and Health|Joint Commission on Mental Illness and Health]], Cambridge, MA, 1957-1958 * [[Statistician]], U.S. [[Bureau of the Census]], Suitland, MD, 1958-1959 * Senior Staff, President [[John F. Kennedy]]'s [[Council of Economic Advisors]], 1961-1963 * Senior Fellow, Economics Study Program, [[The Brookings Institution]], 1963-1968 * Professor of Economics of Medicine, Department of Social Medicine, [[Harvard Medical School]], 1968-1999 * Professor of Economics of Medicine, [[Harvard Kennedy School of Government]], 1968-1999 * Professor of Economics of Medicine Emeritus, Department of Social Medicine, Harvard Medical School, 1995-2014=Recognitions and awards== * Charter (founding) member of the [[Institute of Medicine]] (IOM), a nonprofit NGO founded in 1970.{{cite web|url=https://reachmd.com/profiles/rashi-fein-phd/OXB4vP/|title=Rashi Fein, PhD|website=reachmd.com}} * Founding member, National Academy of Social Insurance * Mumerous honors for his writings in [[medical economics]] * Traveling Fellowship, [[World Health Organization]], 1971 * John M. Russell Medal, Markle Scholars (Markle Fund) for "Advancement of Knowledge in Medicine", 1971{{cite web|url=http://www.transactionpub.com/merchant2/merchant.mvc?Screen=AUTHOR&authorid=15240|title=Transaction - Routledge|website=Routledge.com}} * Martin E. Rehfuss Medal and Lectureship "For Distinguished Service to Medicine" * Theobald Smith Lectureship, [[Albany Medical College]], "For Teaching", Albany, NY, 1976 * Heath Clark Lecturer, London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, 1980, delivered paper "Social and economic attitudes shaping American health policy" on March 24 and 26, 1980{{cite journal|jstor=3349730|title=Social and Economic Attitudes Shaping American Health Policy|first=Rashi|last=Fein|date=17 April 1980|publisher=|journal=The Milbank Memorial Fund Quarterly. Health and Society|volume=58|issue=3|pages=349–385|doi=10.2307/3349730}} * Johns Hopkins University Alumni Association, 1999 * Lifetime Achievement Award "For Fearlessly Promoting the Rights of All to Health Care", Health Care, 2000 * Adam Yarmolinsky Medal from the [[Institute of Medicine]], 2000[http://www.iom.edu/Activities/PublicHealth/MemberAwards/YarmolinskyAwardRecipients.aspx List of Adam Yarmolinsky Award Recipients, IOM website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613232427/http://www.iom.edu/Activities/PublicHealth/MemberAwards/YarmolinskyAwardRecipients.aspx |date=2010-06-13 }} * On June 30, 2009, he received the Debs-Thomas-Bernstein Awards, sponsored by Boston [[Democratic Socialists of America]], in Boston.{{cite web|url=http://www.dsaboston.org/yradical/yr2009-06.pdf|title=TYR, June 2009|website=dsaboston.org}} ==Publications== * ''Economics of Mental Illness'', Basic Books, 1958. * ''The Doctor Shortage: An Economic Diagnosis'', The Brookings Institution, 1967. * ''Financing Medical Education: An Analysis of Alternative Policies and Mechanisms'' (with Gerald I. Weber), McGraw Hill, 1971. * A ''Right to Health: The Problem of Access to Primary Medical Care'' (with Charles Lewis and David Mechanic), John Wiley & Sons, 1976. * ''Employment Impacts of Health Policy Developments'' (with Christine Bishop), Special Report No.11, National Commission for Manpower Policy, 1976. * ''Alcohol in America: The Price We Pay''. California: Care Institute, 1984. * ''Medical Care, Medical Costs: The Search for a Health Insurance Policy'', Harvard University Press, 1986, 1989. * ''The Health Care Mess: How We Got Into It and What It Will Take To Get Out'' (with [[Julius B. {{Infobox building | name = Aqueduct of Santa Clara | native_name = Aqueducto de Santa Clara | native_name_lang = <!-- images --> | logo = | logo_size = | logo_caption = | image = Vila do Conde-Aqueduto de Santa Clara (4).jpg | image_size = | image_caption = Vertical pillars of the aqueduct near the Church of Santa Clara <!-- map --> | map_type = | pushpin_relief = | image_map = | map_caption = Location of the aqueduct within the municipality of [[Vila do Conde]] <!-- location --> | location = [[Vila do Conde]] | address = | location_city = [[Vila do Conde]] | location_country = [[Portugal]] | coordinates = {{coord|41|21|22.7|N|8|44|23.8|W|display=inline,title}} <!-- stats --> | former_names = | alternate_names = | etymology = | status = | cancelled = | topped_out = | building_type = [[Aqueduct (water supply)|Aqueduct]] | architectural_style = [[Medieval architecture|Medieval]] | material = Granite | classification = | altitude = | namesake = | groundbreaking_date = | start_date = | stop_date = | est_completion = | completion_date = | opened_date = 17th century | inauguration_date = | closing_date = | demolition_date = | destruction_date = | cost = | ren_cost = | client = | owner = [[Portugal|Portuguese Republic]] | affiliation = | height = | architectural = | structural_system = | size = | floor_count = | floor_area = | elevator_count = | grounds_area = | architect = Manuel Pinho Villa Lobos | architecture_firm = | developer = | engineer = | known_for = | website = | embed = | embedded = | references = | footnotes = }} The '''Aqueduct of Santa Clara''' is the second largest [[Portugal|Portuguese]] [[aqueduct (bridge)|aqueduct]] system. Built between 1626 and 1714, it includes 999 arches stretching for {{convert|4|km|mi}} from the spring of Terroso in the [[Concelho|municipality]] of [[Póvoa de Varzim]] to the [[Convent of Santa Clara, Vila do Conde|Convent of Santa Clara]] in the municipality of [[Vila do Conde]].
==History== [[File:Igreja de Santa Clara vila do conde aqueduto (2).JPG|thumb|235px|left|Segment of the aqueduct as it meets the convent]] [[File:Aqueduto de Vila do Conde.jpg|thumb|235px|left|Part of the pillars of the 999 arches]] Founded at the beginning of the 14th century, the monastic community of Santa Clara always debated the problems with water supply to the monastery in the territory of Vila do Conde.<ref name="IGESPAR">{{citation|url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.pt/en/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/71209 |title=Aqueduto de Vila do Conde |publisher=Direção-Geral de Património Cultural |editor=GIF/IPPAR |location=Lisbon, Portugal |language=Portuguese |accessdate=16 April 2015 |first=Catarina |last=Oliveira |date=28 February 2005}}</ref> At that time a tank (the ''arca de água'') was constructed within the monastery, which quickly became insufficient to the communities needs.<ref name=IGESPAR/> In 1626, the abbey D. Maria de Meneses, from the House of Pentieiros, purchased lands and contracted a master-builder to construct an aqueduct to bring waters from a spring in Terroso, in Póvoa de Varzim, to support the convent.<ref name=IGESPAR/><ref name="SIPA">{{citation|url=http://www.monumentos.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=3904 |title=Aqueduto de Vila do Conde/Aqueduto de Santa Clara (IPA.00003904/PT011316280006) |publisher=SIPA – Sistema de Informação para o Património Arquitectónico |editor=SIPA |location=Lisbon, Portugal |language=Portuguese |first=Isabel |last=Sereno |first2=Paula |last2=Noé |year=1997 |accessdate=15 April 2015}}</ref> The construction was interrupted by abbey D. Catarina Lima in 1636, owing to the discovery of a significant slope, making the prior work useless.<ref name=IGESPAR/><ref name=SIPA/>
On 19 December 1705, the project was restarted, under abbess D. Bárbara Micaela de Ataíde, from the House of Honra e Barbosa, in Penafiel.<ref name=IGESPAR/> The abbess put the project under the direction of captain Domingos Lopes, from Porto and artillery lieutenant-general Manuel de Villa Lobos.<ref name=IGESPAR/><ref name=SIPA/> Further support for the project was obtained by D. Bárbara de Ataíde, who (along with sisters D. Maria Ângela and D. Maria António) and brother D. Manuel de Azevedo de Ataíde (Military Governor of the Province of Minho) petitioned the King to provide a private judge and exempt the workers from military service.<ref name=SIPA/> Although the project was tendered to masterbuilder João Rodrigues (from Ponta de Lima), but failed to complete the project.<ref name=SIPA/> It was then passed to Domingos Moreira (from Moreira da Maia), who was tasked to complete the project and paid 4400$00 [[Portuguese real|réis]].<ref name=SIPA/>
The first waters reached the convent's cloister on 20 October 1714.<ref name=IGESPAR/><ref name=SIPA/>
By 2 October 1739, the Congregation of Rites confirmed the excommunication of people caught stealing water from the aqueduct.<ref name=SIPA/>
Somewhere around Casal do Monte, during a storm on 10 June 1794, 46 arches were knocked down.<ref name=SIPA/>
Between 1929 and 1932, there was an intentional deconstruction of five arches, during the restoration of the Church of Santa Clara, in order to improve the view of the apse.<ref name=SIPA/>
A tender was issued in January 2004, in order promote the conservation and consolidate the structure.<ref name=SIPA/>
On 25 November 2006, the spaces surrounding the aqueduct were requalified (between the monastery of Santa Clara and ''Rua da Lada''), authored by architect Manuel Maia Gomes, who received the ''Alexandre Herculano National Architecture Award'' by the ''Associação Portuguesa dos Municípios'' (APMCH), the ''Portuguese Municipal Association''.<ref name=SIPA/> Yet, although the structure was legally protected in 1910, several arches fell as recently as December 2009 and the destroyed arches were not recovered.<ref name=SIPA/> This problem mostly affects the area of the monument located in Póvoa de Varzim, due to lack of maintenance, a responsibility of the national government.
==Architecture== The aqueduct is located in a rural environment, isolated and elevated position, annexed to existing structures; some parts of the aqueduct are connected to the Convent of Santa Clara and the Convent of Nossa Senhora da Encarnação.<ref name=SIPA/>
The artificial canal extends from the convent to the spring, an extension formed by 999 arches.<ref name=IGESPAR/><ref name=SIPA/> Of the original structure, a great part of the early aqueduct has been weakened over time, not including the segment from the Church of Santa Clara until the municipal limits, an extension of {{convert|500|m|ft}} of {{convert|4|km|mi}}.<ref name=IGESPAR/><ref name=SIPA/> The aqueduct has a decreasing arcade span and height, with pointed arches and a rounded upper channel profile.<ref name=IGESPAR/><ref name=SIPA/>

Augusto |title=Vila do Conde e seu Alfoz. Origens e Monumentos |location=Porto, Portugal |year=1923 |language=Portuguese}} * {{citation |last=Gonçalves |first=Flávio |title=Dois Monumentos in Brotéria |volume=XLVII |issue=5 |location=Lisbon, Portugal |year=1948 |language=Portuguese}} * {{citation |last=Basto |first=A. de Magalhães |title=Falam Velhos Manuscritos...A construção do famoso Aqueduto do Real Mosteiro de Santa Clara de Vila do Conde, O Primeiro de Janeiro |location=Porto, Portugal |date=30 December 1949 |language=Portuguese}} * {{citation |last=Freitas |first=Eugénio de Andrea da Cunha e |contribution=O Aqueduto de Santa Clara de Vila do Conde |title=Boletim Vila do Conde |issue=2 |location=Barcelos, Portugal |year=1961 |language=Portuguese}} * {{citation |last=Basto |first=A. de Magalhães |title=Apontamentos para um Dicionário de Artistas |location=Porto, Portugal |year=1961 |language=Portuguese}} * {{citation |last=Neves |first=Joaquim Pacheco |title=Vila do Conde |location=Vila do Conde, Portugal |year=1991 |language=Portuguese}} * {{citation |last=Marques |first=Ângelo Teixeira |title=Aqueduto em risco de ruína |publisher=Público |date=15 January 1997 |language=Portuguese}} * {{citation |last=Marques |first=Ana Trocado |contribution=Notícias com rosto |title=Jornal de Noticias |date=25 November 2006 |language=Portuguese}}

| commercial = No | type = [[Blog]] | language = English | registration = | owner = | author = | launch date = 2008<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://sciencebasedmedicine.org/hello-world/|title=Announcing '''''Science-Based Medicine''''' is a website with articles covering issues in [[science]] and [[medicine]],<ref name="Johannes">{{cite news|last1=Johannes|first1=Laura|title=Will Getting Grounded Help You Sleep Better and Ease Pain?|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304652804579572072977644460|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=[[Wall Street Journal]]|date=19 May 2014}}</ref><ref name="Osborne">{{cite news|last1=Osborne|first1=Hannah|title=Clinical Trials of Homeopathy 'Essentially Test Whether Magic Works', Experts Say|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/clinical-trials-homeopathy-essentially-test-whether-magic-works-experts-say-1461936|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=[[International Business Times]]|date=20 August 2014}}</ref> especially dangerous [[quackery|medical scams and practices]].<ref name="Lipson">{{cite news|last1=Lipson|first1=Peter|title=Alleged Medical Expert Mike Adams Attacks Respected Cancer Doctor|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/peterlipson/2016/05/05/alleged-medical-expert-mike-adams-attacks-respected-cancer-doctor/|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=[[Forbes]]|date=5 May 2016}}</ref> ''Science-Based Medicine'' is noted as an influential and respected source of information about medical controversies and [[alternative medicine]].<ref name="Freedman">{{cite news|last1=Freedman|first1=David H.|title=The Triumph of New-Age Medicine|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2011/07/the-triumph-of-new-age-medicine/308554/|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=[[The Atlantic]]|date=July–August 2011}}</ref><ref name="Senapathy">{{cite news|last1=Senapathy|first1=Kavin|title=Why Is Big Naturopathy Afraid Of This Lone Whistleblower?|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kavinsenapathy/2016/05/31/why-is-big-naturopathy-afraid-of-this-lone-whistleblower|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=[[Forbes]]|date=31 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="Schwarcz">{{cite news|last1=Joe|first1=Schwarcz|authorlink1=Joseph A. Schwarcz|title=The Right Chemistry: 'Is it safe to kiss your golf balls?'|url=http://montrealgazette.com/technology/science/the-right-chemistry-is-it-safe-to-kiss-your-golf-balls|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=[[Montreal Gazette]]|date=17 July 2015}}</ref><ref name="Gifford">{{cite news|last1=Gifford|first1=Bill|title=This is What You Get When You Look to TV Stars for Health Advice: Suzanne Somers, Dangerous Medical Hack|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/115574/suzanne-somers-hormone-hackery-unscientific-and-dangerous|work=[[The New Republic]]|date=13 November 2013|accessdate=3 September 2016}}</ref><ref name="Moyer">{{cite news|last1=Moyer|first1=Melinda Wenner|title=Does Fluoride Make Your Kids Dumb?|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/double_x/the_kids/2013/02/does_fluoride_lower_your_child_s_iq_dr_joseph_mercola_says_yes_on_the_huffington.html|accessdate=3 September 2016|work=[[Slate (magazine) |Slate]]|date=11 February 2013}}</ref>
[[Steven Novella]], a clinical neurologist at [[Yale University]], founded the site as a blog and serves as its executive editor.<ref name="McNamee">{{cite news|last1=McNamee|first1=David|title=Why is scientific literacy among the general population important?|url=http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/281470.php|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=[[Medical News Today]]|date=22 August 2014}}</ref><ref name="Stein">{{cite news|last1=Stein|first1=Rob|title=FDA Ponders Putting Homeopathy To A Tougher Test|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2015/04/20/398806514/fda-ponders-whether-homeopathy-is-medicine|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=[[NPR]]|date=20 April 2015}}</ref> [[David Gorski]], a surgical oncologist at [[Wayne State University]], serves as the managing editor.<ref name="Harvey">{{cite news|last1=Harvey|first1=Chelsea|title=How cases like Flint destroy public trust in science|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/energy-environment/wp/2016/01/27/how-cases-like-flint-destroy-public-trust-in-science/|accessdate=30 June 2016|work=[[Washington Post]]|date=27 January 2016}}</ref><ref name="Walker">{{cite news|last1=Walker|first1=Connie|last2=Luke|first2=Marnie|title=Health Canada investigates Florida spa director's illegal supplements|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/investigates/supplements-clement-six-nations-1.3570751|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=[[CBC News]]|date=7 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="Bradley">{{cite news|last1=Bradley|first1=Fikes|title=Most biomed studies irreproducible, reviews find|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/2016/jan/04/biomedical-studies-not-reproducible/|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]]|date=4 January 2016}}</ref> Both editors and the blog's regular contributors are prominent [[scientific skepticism|skeptics]], doctors, researchers, and communicators.<ref name="Lipson"/>
==Editorial staff== The ''Science-Based Medicine'' editorial staff describes themselves as "being alarmed at the manner in which unscientific and [[pseudoscientific]] health care ideas have increasingly infiltrated academic medicine and medicine at large"; they state that the best medicine is based on [[scientific principles]], which includes prior plausibility, not based on [[evidence]] alone.<ref name="SBMeditors">{{cite web|title=Editors|url=https://www.sciencebasedmedicine.org/editorial-staff/|website=Science-Based Medicine|accessdate=24 August 2016}}</ref>
The editors are:<ref name="SBMeditors" />
*[[Steven Novella]]<ref name="McNamee" /><ref name="Stein" /> *[[David Gorski]]<ref name="Harvey" /><ref name="Walker" /> *[[Harriet Hall]]<ref name="Robertson">{{cite news|last1=Robertson|first1=Blair|title=Despite safety benefits, there’s no consensus on bike helmets|url=http://www.sacbee.com/entertainment/living/health-fitness/article78558542.html|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=[[The Sacramento Bee]]|date=18 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="Branswell">{{cite news|last1=Branswell|first1=Helen|title=Spurious Lyme disease ‘cures’ proliferate on web, study finds|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/health-and-fitness/health/therapies-available-online-raise-concerns-over-lyme-disease-cures/article24617431/|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=26 May 2015}}</ref> *[[Kimball Atwood]]<ref name="Weber">{{cite news|last1=Weber|first1=Nina|title=Asthma-Patienten: Placebo-Studie erzürnt US-Mediziner|url=http://www.spiegel.de/wissenschaft/medizin/asthma-patienten-placebo-studie-erzuernt-us-mediziner-a-780463.html|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=[[Der Spiegel]]|date=18 August 2011|language=German}}</ref><ref name="Lilienfeld">{{cite news|last1=Lilienfeld|first1=Scott|title=Evidence-Based Practice: The Misunderstandings Continue|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/the-skeptical-psychologist/201401/evidence-based-practice-the-misunderstandings-continue|work=[[Psychology Today]]|date=27 January 2014}}</ref>
Past editors have been:<ref name="SBMeditors" />
* Wally Sampson * Paul Ingraham<ref name="Ng">{{cite news|url=http://guardianlv.com/2014/05/placebo-effect-why-people-believe-it-works-video/|title=Placebo Effect: Why People Believe 'It Works' [Video] · Guardian Liberty Voice|last1=Ng|first1=Nick|date=17 May 2014|work=Guardian Liberty Voice|accessdate=23 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Mark Crislip]]<ref name="Painter">{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/2016/07/17/dry-needling-acupuncture-pain/86940278/|title='Dry needling' for pain therapy is under scrutiny|last1=Painter|first1=Kim|date=17 July 2016|work=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=23 August 2016}}</ref>

{{multiple issues| {{technical|date=August 2013}} {{update|date=August 2013}} {{manual|date=January 2012}} }}
'''Total conversation''' is an ITU standard of simultaneous video, voice and text service in telecommunications. Total conversation allows people in two or more locations to: (a) see each other, (b) hear each other, and (c) conduct a text interaction ([[real-time text]]) with each other, or choose to communicate with any combination of those three modes and to do so in real-time.<ref>[http://www.realtimetext.org/index.php?pagina=61 Total Conversation explained at realtimetext.org]</ref>
The standard was defined in [[ITU-T]] recommendation F.703<ref>[http://www.itu.int/rec/T-REC-F.703-200011-I/en F.703 : Multimedia conversational services]</ref> of 2000 as "an audiovisual conversation service providing bidirectional symmetric real-time transfer of motion video, text and voice between users in two or more locations".
== Application ==
* Conference call for businesses will need to use audio and text and may use video to share documents. * Deaf people using [[sign language]] would be more than satisfied to call each other with video. * Deaf people using sign language can also call, and be called by hearing people using [[Video Relay Service]]. * Hard of hearing people to call each other directly with voice and text and even video for lip-reading. * Hard of hearing and deaf people who do not use sign language (orally and late deafened) need to access a [[Text Relay Service]] with an audio plus text call in order to be able to speak but also to receive captions. * Text-only call is the only way to make a call for deaf-blind user using [[Braille]] display. * Text call mixed to audio feedback is the only way to make a call for speech disabled user * video, text and audio combined call is the only suitable way to make a call for cognitive disabled user. * Text only call might be convenient in situation when audio communication is not permitted, available or dangerous (noisy situation, low bandwidth). * Support and hot line might be contacted with an audio-only call and add a video stream if the user needs to show the actual issue he or she is facing on a device.
== Universal design ==
Total conversation is a straightforward application of [[universal design]] principles applied to telecommunication field. This standard brings communication services to the broadest range of population including deaf people, hard or hearing people but also people who have speech impairment, people with cognitive impairment, elderly people, children, and also ... regular users. It is an enhancement of call services that provides a better experience to all. Total conversation uses video, text and audio. These media can be combined or not depending on the type of profile used : many user profiles have to be taken into account. Such methodology is named Universal Design.
== Implementation of the standard ==
=== Available implementations ===
A number of European companies including 4CTel, Aupix, IVèS, nWise, Omnitor, and Orange Labs produced implementations. These are mostly used to provide user-to-user calls and [[relay services]] for deaf and hard of hearing people.
=== REACH112 ===
Total conversation was piloted in a European project called REACH112,<ref>[http://www.reach112.eu Reach112 project website]</ref> named after the [[1-1-2]] European emergency number, whose purpose was to carry out test deployment of total conversation in a live environment with several thousands users and for three usages:
* European wide person to person calls * Total Conversation Relay Services for deaf people * Total Conversation used for emergency calls.
=== Specifications ===
Total conversation specifications describe:
* An interconnection interface between total conversation service providers including relay services. * A user to network interface for videophone manufacturers. * A call interface for Next Generation Emergency Services in Europe Europe<ref>[http://www.eena.org/view/en/Committees/NG112.html Next Generation 112] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929225731/http://www.eena.org/view/en/Committees/NG112.html |date=2011-09-29 }}</ref> including an information sharing capability.
Total conversation defines three basic services
* seamless multimedia person to person calls including the ability to call regular telephone users. * the ability to invoke a relay service by deaf or hard of hearing persons, * the ability to call emergency services in total conversation mode.
Example of technical protocols used by total conversation are:
* [[Session Initiation Protocol]] for call signalling, * T.140<ref>[http://www.itu.int/rec/T-REC-T.140/fr T.140 : T.140]</ref> with an RFC 4103.<ref>[http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4103 RFC4103 RTP Payload for T.140]</ref> for real-time text<ref>[[Text over IP|RTT in SIP: Text over IP (ToIP)]]</ref> (RTT) * Video codecs [[H.263]] and preferably [[H.264]]. * Audio codec ITU-T G.711 and other as commonly used in VoIP calls. (* Use of [[Common Alerting Protocol]] may be also considered to share information with Emergency Services.)
== Over instant messaging ==
[[AOL Instant Messenger]] supports the simultaneous use of audio, video, and real-time text via the "Real-Time IM"<ref>[http://help.aol.com/help/microsites/microsite.do?cmd=displayKC&docType=kc&externalId=223568 AOL Instant Messenger "Real-Time IM"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120312102140/http://help.aol.com/help/microsites/microsite.do?cmd=displayKC&docType=kc&externalId=223568 |date=2012-03-12 }}</ref> feature. This would be considered compliant with Total Conversation.
For other chat networks such as [[Google Talk]], the [[Extensible Messaging and Presence Protocol|XMPP]] protocol technically allow for total conversation by combining multiple XMPP Extensions, such as XEP-0266 audio,<ref>[http://xmpp.org/extensions/xep-0266.html XEP-0266 Codecs for Jingle Audio]</ref> XEP-0299 video,<ref>[http://xmpp.org/extensions/xep-0266.html XEP-0299 Codecs for Jingle Video]</ref> and XEP-0301 real-time text.<ref>[http://xmpp.org/extensions/xep-0301.html XEP-0301 In-Band Real-Time Text]</ref> As of December 2011, Google Talk only supports audio/video, but not real-time text yet.
[[Skype]] has been supporting simultaneous audio, video, and real-time text.
== IP multimedia subsystem ==
Total conversation basically provides a multi-media call services with specific media enabled. The currently most common implementation environment is native SIP as described above.
Total conversation can also be implemented in other call control environments. One such environment is [[IP Multimedia Subsystem]] (IMS) in its IMS multimedia telephony service.
Firstly, total conversation can be defined as a pragmatic selection of existing standards related to [[Session Initiation Protocol]] with the selection of audio, video and text codecs. It is a private initiative of services provider and technology vendors seeking interoperability in the broadtest sense.
Secondly, this can apply to existing and deployed SIP platform rather than future or next generation networks.
Thirdly, IMS is much more ambitious and define a whole architecture, including all internal interfaces and billing and physical infrastructure. These standards are more suitable for large telecommunication operators and their equipment vendors. This complexity has consequences:
* Very little UMTS release 5 networks fully supporting IMS are in production<ref>[http://www.vision2mobile.com/articles/2007/01/ims-reality-check.aspx IMS Reality check]</ref> * Multimedia call services defined by MMTEL are not translated<ref>[http://seekingalpha.com/article/64004-ims-mmtel-does-anyone-other-than-ericsson-care MMTel does anyone other than Ericsson care?]</ref> in actual usable services on the market. An industry led initiative called Rich Communication Suite<ref>[http://www.ericsson.com/ericsson/news/archive/2008/080207_richcomm.shtml RIch Communication Suite]</ref> finally plans to do this .. when IMS will be rolled out in the networks. * Rolling out a Native SIP Total Conversation services needs investments that are very reduced compared to the IMS equivalent. However, the implementations in both environments are close enough that interoperability between the two is an easy task.

The '''Uganda Dental Association''' (UDA) is a registered non-governmental organization that brings together all the qualified dental surgeons retired or practicing in Uganda.<ref name= UDAGlobal >{{cite web|url= http://www.global-caries-initiative.org/dassociationsrch/search.html?dassociationsrchtext=&typedassociationsrch=3 |title= Over 150 local National Dental Associations are supporting us |publisher= FDI Global Caries Initiative}}</ref> Headquartered in Uganda's capital city [[Kampala]], the UDA serves its members and the public by managing key oral health issues on their behalf and by coordinating dental health awareness programs across the nation.<ref name= UDAUG >{{cite web|url= http://www.suvison.com/net/sc_aww_fp.asp?id=8369 |title= ASSOCIATIONS WORLDWIDE |publisher= SUVISION}}</ref><ref name= UDACW >{{cite web|url= http://www.comdental.org/links.php |title= Useful Links |publisher= The Commonwealth Dental Association}}</ref><ref name= UDAaware >{{cite web|url= http://allafrica.com/stories/201404010294.html |title= Uganda: Insufficient Dentists As Dental Cases Escalate |publisher= allAfrica}}</ref>
The core objective of the UDA is to promote advancement of dentistry through the exchange of ideas amongst dental surgeons, in Uganda and the world. The association uses its leadership role to ensure that the rights and privileges of the members are enjoyed by all and acts as a watchdog to regulate the dental profession in Uganda. The association also ensures that the expectations of the public are met and is actively involved with lobbying and advocacy initiatives.<ref name= UDA1 >{{cite web|url= http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/459/702188 |title= Oral health should be given priority |publisher= New Vision}}</ref>
The UDA publishes an annual journal of dental related articles called ''UDA Journal''. Every November, the UDA fraternity marks ''Dental Health Week'' with media campaigns, screening and treatment for dental diseases and dental health education through outreach to the underserved communities.<ref name= UDAJ >{{cite web|url= http://www.ugadent.org/uda-journal/ |title= UDA Journal |publisher= UDA}}</ref><ref name= UDA1 /> On 20 March each year, the UDA joins the world in observing [[World Oral Health Day]] (WOHD) by organizing special awareness campaigns and clinics.<ref name= WOHD >{{cite web|url= http://www.worldoralhealthday.com/uganda-celebrates-wohd-2014/ |title= Uganda celebrates WOHD 2014 |publisher= FDI: World Dental Federation}}</ref><ref name= WOHD2 >{{cite web|url= http://www.ugadent.org/world-oral-health-day/ |title= Uganda celebrates healthy smiles on World Oral Health Day |publisher= The UDA}}</ref>
==History== The UDA was founded in the 1960s by five dentists, namely; Dr.Jack Barlow, Dr.Bisase Arnold, Dr.Aliker Okello, Dr. Amooti Twamirimo Nkurukenda and Dr. William B. Nganwa. In the 1970s during President [[Idi Amin]]'s regime, the association became inactive after the murder of Dr.Jack Barlow by president Amin. It was later revived in the 1980s by Dr. George W. Ssamula together with Dr. William B. Nganwa and Dr. J. F. Tiromwe. As of 2014, the UDA has more than 280 members. In 2010 the UDA published the first ''UDA Journal''. The first UDA office was at [[Mulago Hospital]]. The current UDA headquarters were opened at the Department of Dentistry [[Makerere University]], in 2013.
==Function== The organisation provides continued dental education to its members through workshops, monthly UDA Meetings and UDA journals.<ref name= UDAservices /> The UDA provides a platform for dentists to network nationally and internationally. The organisation helps dentists to engage in outreach programmes and events which benefit both the community and the member. The UDA provides additional credibility to dental practitioners Uganda.
Also, the dental association provides group discounts on professional fees paid by its members; for example Group Professional Indemnity. Finally, the association lends books and DVDs to its members.<ref name= UDAservices >{{cite web|url= http://www.ugadent.org/services/ |title= Services |publisher= UDA}}</ref>
===Regulation of dentists=== The UDA acts as a watchdog to regulate the dental profession in Uganda in collaboration with the [[Uganda Medical & Dental Practitioners Council]] (UMDPC) which is mandated by Uganda’s [[Ministry of Health]] to regulate professional Medical Officers and Dental Surgeons in the country.<ref name= UDA1 /> The UDA has a representative on the UMDPC Board as per the Medical and Dental Practitioners Act 1998.<ref name= UMDPC >{{cite web|url= http://umdpc.com/ |title= Welcome to Uganda Medical & Dental Practitioners Council |publisher= UMDPC}}</ref><ref name= MDPact >{{cite web|url= http://www.ulii.org/ug/legislation/consolidated-act/272 |title= Medical and Dental Practitioners Act 1998 |publisher= ULII}}</ref>
==Membership== The association consists of Dental Surgeons, Honorary Members and Associate members qualified and/or with a professional connection with dentistry in Uganda. Qualified dentists must be registered with the Association, and thereafter with the Uganda Medical and Dental Practitioners Council upon payment of the levied charges and Professionals other than dentists whose work is related to dentistry may apply for membership of the association.<ref name= UDAmembership >{{cite web|url= http://www.ugadent.org/member-composition/ |title= Member Composition |publisher= UDA}}</ref>
The UDA is a member of various international bodies like [[FDI World Dental Federation|FDI]] and the Commonwealth Dental Association (CDA).
The association has a unique and innovative partnership with [[Wrigleys]]. The UDA is promoting good oral hygiene and practice in communities around Uganda through [http://www.wrigleydentalcare.com/ The Wrigley Oral Healthcare Program]. [[Colgate-Palmolive|Colgate]] and [[GlaxoSmithKline]] (GSK) usually sponsor the UDA’s countrywide initiatives.<ref name= UDAColg >{{cite web|url= http://www.independent.co.ug/business/business-briefs/4695-colgate-launches-new-brand |title= Colgate launches new brand |publisher= UNICAF}}</ref><ref name= WOHD2 />
==Publications== It subscribes to over 100 dental journals and provides members with free [[MEDLINE]] searches. The UDA produces regular dental publications, such as the ''UDA Journal'' (for clinical articles and jobs).<ref name= UDAJ />

A '''vaginal dilator''' (sometimes called a vaginal trainer<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Vaginismus/Pages/Treatment.aspx|title=Vaginismus|publisher=[[National Health Service]] }}</ref>) is an instrument used to gently stretch the [[vagina]]. They are used when the vagina has become narrowed ([[vaginal stenosis]]), such as after [[brachytherapy]] for gynecologic cancers,<ref name=Cochrane/> and as therapy for [[vaginismus]] and other forms of [[dyspareunia]].<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/01443610050009683 |first1=T. O. |last1=Idama |first2=D. W. |last2=Pring |title=Vaginal dilator therapy-an outpatient gynaecological option in the management of dyspareunia |journal=Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology |volume=20 |year=2000 |issue=3 |pages=303–05 |doi=10.1080/01443610050009683 }}</ref>
There is mixed evidence for their use, and studies have reported psychological damage from dilator treatment. [[Rectovaginal fistula]]e have also been linked to dilator use.<ref name=Cochrane>{{cite journal |last1=Miles |first1=Tracie |last2=Johnson |first2=Neal |title=Vaginal dilator therapy for women receiving pelvic radiotherapy |journal=Cochrane Database Syst Rev |volume=9 |issue= |pages=CD007291 |year=2014 |pmid=25198150 |doi=10.1002/14651858.CD007291.pub3 |pmc=4171967 |url=http://cochranelibrary-wiley.com/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD007291.pub3/full }}</ref>
{{anchor|vaginal stent}} Vaginal dilators, also called '''vaginal stents''', are used routinely in postoperative care for patients who have undergone [[sex reassignment surgery (male-to-female)]]. The dilator is used immediately after surgery to keep the passage from healing, and regularly thereafter to maintain the viability of the [[neovagina]]. Frequency of use requirements decrease over time, but remains obligatory lifelong.<ref name="Rinzler-2010">{{cite book |last=Rinzler |first=Carol Ann |title=The Encyclopedia of Cosmetic and Plastic Surgery |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N5nWmFCbYqcC&pg=PA195 |series=Facts on File library of health and living. |date=12 May 2010 |publisher=Infobase Publishing |location=New York |isbn=978-1-4381-2702-6 |page=195 |oclc=223107099 |accessdate=31 May 2018}}</ref><ref name="Georgiade-1992">{{cite book |last1=Georgiade |first1=Gregory S. |last2=Georgiade |first2=Nicholas G. |title=Textbook of plastic, maxillofacial, and reconstructive surgery |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=snJsAAAAMAAJ |year=1992 |publisher=Williams & Wilkins |location=Baltimore, Maryland |isbn=978-0-683-03454-7 |oclc=455225627 |accessdate=31 May 2018}}</ref>
